column46:
Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS) is pleased to announce the opening of our St. Andrew's Nursing Home (SANH) (Taman Jurong), in February 2019. SANH (Taman Jurong) is one of Ministry of Health's latest Build-Own-Lease projects. Located on Yung Ho Walk, it is a 290-bed home, catering to people requiring long-term nursing care (including those with mental health issues). As SACS is an established service provider of psychiatric rehabilitation and senior services, the opening of SANH (Taman Jurong) will augment our spectrum of care services. (For more information on SACS, please visit www.sacs.org.sg).

Our operation is partially funded by government subsidies and fees collected. We have to rely on donations to keep our charges affordable and to provide value-added programmes to enrich our residents' well-being. For a start, we expect an annual shortfall of between $500,000 and $1m.

SACS is blessed to have the Republic of Singapore Yacht Club share our mission to care. Together, we will be organising a Charity Golf & Dinner. We would like to invite you to support this fundraising effort by participating in the golf game and dinner or with an outright donation.
column47:
Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS), is a work produced by FAITH, an endurance nurtured by HOPE, and a labour prompted by LOVE. The early 1950s marked the genesis of SACS, with the setting up of a clinic by Mrs. Francis Thomas, a nurse and the wife of the Principal of St. Andrew's School. The clinic was to serve villagers living in the Potong Pasir area. 

In 1967, the Anglican Welfare Council - renamed Singapore Anglican Welfare Council (SAWC) in 1977 - was inaugurated to serve the needs of the community. SAWC was restructured to bring together the other community service arm of the Anglican Church in Singapore, and was renamed Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS) in 2004.

Presently, SACS is a voluntary welfare organisation and an approved Institution of Public Character. SACS serves the community through our care services in three areas: Psychiatric Services, Senior Services as well as Family and Children Services.

column46:
Biscuits and water to stop the feeling of hunger.

This is a very real experience for some of our needy beneficiaries.
Eating a proper meal can be a luxury when you do not have enough money for other critical needs such as utilities, school fees and medical bills.  With Food from the Heart, our beneficiaries are guaranteed monthly food packs and bread rations.

Watch the video and find out how Food from the Heart provides hope and nourishment to our beneficiaries like Mary.
column47:
Food from the Heart is a charity founded in February 2003 by Singapore-based Austrian couple Henry and Christine Laimer, who were inspired to channel surplus food from bakeries to families in need after they read an article about bread wastage. 

Today, Food from the Heart is Singapore's foremost independent food charity with IPC status that makes a tangible and meaningful contribution to fighting hunger through bread rations and food packs. With the support of donors, food industry partners and more than 10,000 volunteers, Food from the Heart made a difference to the lives of 53,700 people throughout Singapore by distributing S$6.35 million worth of food in 2020.

Mission
To alleviate hunger by providing reliable, consistent and sustainable food support to the less-fortunate through food distribution programmes.

For more information, please visit www.foodfromtheheart.sg.

column46:
SportCares nurtures a national movement that activates sport as a force for social good.  SportCares works to inspire and enable children & youth at-risk, persons with disabilities & special needs and vulnerable seniors.  

Through sports:

We learn to better understand our constituents, their situations and their needs; helping them overcome barriers to a life of growth and confidence.  

We build stronger communities, forging connections and finding common ground between organisations and individuals to socialise and do good together.  

We stand in partnership with others, collaborating with public, private and government organisations as part of integrated solutions to address and solve complex problems. 

You can support SportCares by volunteering your time, playing on our team or donating through Giving.SG. (All donations to SportCares above $10 will generate a tax credit of 2.5 times the original amount for the donor.)

Equally important, if you know someone or a group that could do with a helping hand from SportCares, please reach out to us through sportcares@sport.gov.sg
column47:

Please go to One Team Singapore Campaign (www.giving.sg/vision2030/oneteamsingapore) or SportCares Campaign (https://www.giving.sg/vision2030/sportcares)  if you wish to donate to a specific cause.

column46:
The Singapore Art Museum will be undergoing redevelopment of its buildings to create an iconic museum space for contemporary art in Singapore. Part of this major undertaking is the conservation and preservation of the buildings' heritage architecture, thoughtfully blending the old and the new.

We invite you to contribute to SAM's capital fundraising campaign and enjoy an exclusive portrait session* with celebrity photographer Russel Wong within SAM's beautiful buildings.

These special portrait sessions are unique commemorative occasions specifically created to capture treasured memories in SAM as keepsakes for our patrons before the buildings are significantly transformed over the next few years. 

Donations begin at $10,000 and all proceeds will support the redevelopment efforts to create public spaces and new art spaces where everyone can enjoy, experience and engage with contemporary art.

For more information, please contact partnership@singaporeartmuseum.sg or 6697 9740.
column47:
Singapore Art Museum opened in 1996 as the first art museum in Singapore. Also known as SAM, we present contemporary art from a Southeast Asian perspective for artists, art lovers and the art curious.

SAM is building one of the world's most important public collections of Southeast Asian contemporary art, and as a non-profit arts institution - it is our responsibility to preserve, research, exhibit and connect the art and artists to the public and future generations through thought-provoking exhibitions and meaningful programmes.

column46:
A fundraising event for our new Home!  Our Gala Dinner will be held on 24th August 2019, at the Jubilee Garden at SAFRA Toa Payoh.

We are constructing a new 5-storey Home as the land-lease for the land we currently occupy had expired in Dec 2015.
The new building needs $15 million to complete and we are still in need of $5 million to complete our new Home.

As part of the Bicentennial Celebrations, the Singapore Government will grant dollar for dollar matching for donations raised by IPCs in between 1 April 2019 and 31 Mar 2020, up to a cap of $400,000 per IPC.  Tote Board will also grant our Home 40% of funds raised for this event.

Please join us and help us complete our new Home for our elderly residents!
column47:
Established in December 1958, St. John's Home for Elderly Persons is a Sheltered Home for elderly persons who are ambulant and aged above 60.

Our Mission is to provide shelter and care to meet the physical and spiritual needs of elderly persons who have no home and no children or close relatives with adequate resources to care for them.

The Home is open to all regardless of race or creed.

We are not a Government-subvented Home and depend largely on the public's generosity to enable us to continue our work. Your donations will be greatly appreciated.

Support us so our clients can continue to receive free counselling. Your donation will allow us to conduct public educations to reduce the stigma associated with mental illness. 

Silver Ribbon (Singapore) (SRS) has been providing psycho-emotional support for people who are coping with a mental health condition and their caregivers since 2006. We conduct public education to raise awareness on mental wellness and encourage early treatment too. There are currently 3 branches and we hope to raise funds to continue to support the cause and good work. Your contribution, no matter the amount, help us to work towards a more inclusive society and acceptance of people who are struggling with mental health issues. Thank you!
column47:
Current Fundraising Campaign: "Mental Wellness Awareness" via 'Our Campaign' tab.

Silver Ribbon (Singapore) was set up in 2006 and launched by our late President S R Nathan. Our aim is to education the public on positive mental health and encourage early help-seeking attitude. Our team has been working with various stakeholders to raise awareness on mental health and conducting trainings to both the public and private sectors on some signs and symptoms of common mental illness.

Our Vision
Positive attitude towards mental health among the community.

Our Mission
To combat mental health stigma, encourage early treatment and facilitate integration of people with mental illness within the society through innovative means of promoting mental health literacy.

Our Objectives
a. To provide information on the types of mental health services available in Singapore.
b. To raise awareness of mental health issues & promote the eradication of stigma & prejudice against persons with mental disorders.
c. To provide basic

column47:
Brahm Centre's mission is to Promote Happier & Healthier Living to counter mental and physical health challenges. 

Our Vision is to Empower Every Individual To Create Her/His Own Happiness

We provide support and assistance to seniors, befriending services, counselling services and an Assistline to support parents and students who are in distress. We also offer academic coaching to students. 

We offer health talks, music & movement and physio- gym sessions, therapeutic yoga, art coures and excursions.

Our signature programs are Mindfulness Foundation Course, Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction course , Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy course and Mindfulness Retreats.

column46:
Mercy Relief, is Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in Asia Pacific. Our projects span across 25 countries and touched more than 2 million lives addressing education, healthcare, shelter, water & sanitation and sustainable livelihoods.

This year, Mercy Relief are committed to further improve on our provision and delivery of aid. Hence we need your support to donate to our  'Impact Fund' to help us achieve this vision and be better prepared with response for future disasters. Donations to our Impact Fund will enjoy a 250% tax exemption.
column47:
Headquartered in Singapore, Mercy Relief was established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in the Asia Pacific. Today, we are Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency with dedicated leadership, capacity building expertise and an affiliate network operating across the entire disaster management cycle.

Mercy Relief provides emergency aid within 72 hours of an international appeal in the aftermath of a disaster. The objective of our longer-term sustainable development programmes is to uplift and empower communities in five key areas: water & sanitation, shelter, sustainable livelihoods, healthcare and education. For the past 17 years, Mercy Relief has responded to more than 86 human tragedies with more than $44.6 million in relief across 26 countries. We have implemented more than 72 post disaster projects and impacted over 2.6 million lives. 

Find more information about how Mercy Relief is transforming lives across Asia at www.mercyrelief.org.

column46:
Join us for our annual fundraising event, APSN Charity Dinner 2019, which celebrates key milestones and features our beneficiaries' skills and talents. 

Themed 'Powers Uncovered', this occassion tells the stories of three beneficiaries who have demonstrated immense resilience to excel in their respective fields in spite of their intellectual disability. The programme will also feature an inclusive dinner service and exciting line-up of performances by our beneficiaries.

All proceeds generated from the event will be channelled towards education and training programmes to continue empowering our beneficiaries.
column47:
Established in 1976, APSN is a social service agency providing special education for our community with mild intellectual disability (IQ 50-70). Today, APSN operates four Special Education (SPED) Schools (APSN Chaoyang School, APSN Katong School, APSN Tanglin School and APSN Delta Senior School) for students aged 7 to 21, an APSN Student Care Centre for children aged 7 to 18 and an APSN Centre for Adults for persons aged 16 and older, benefiting over 1,200 beneficiaries each year.

The APSN Schools and Centres adopt a holistic approach in its curriculum, comprising academic, vocational and social skills, which are important for open employment and lifelong learning. APSN seeks to enable persons with special needs to be active contributors of the society and is committed to inspire and build capabilities of its partners and community to lead and advocate an inclusive society.
To date, APSN's growing database has more than 5,000 beneficiaries, comprising students, trainees and alumni. The Association is constan

column46:
To celebrate iFly Singapore's 8th Anniversary, iFly Singapore has organised an event to invite our students from AWWA School down to experience the thrill of indoor flying on 24 May 2019. Our students will be flying for a 4-hour period, and we will aim to succeed in the Guinness Book of Records for the most number of continuous tandem skydives. 

How you can support: 
Members of the public are invited to support the event by pledging a base amount per flight. The total donation depends on the total number of flights completed. 

For example, if you pledge a base amount of $1 per flight, and there were 300 flights completed in the 4-hour period, your total donation would be $300. Please key in your donation accordingly. 

All proceeds raised will be used to fund the 2nd AWWA School, which will be operational in 2021. The new AWWA School is a Special Education school appointed by the Ministry of Education to provide special education to 300 students aged 7 to 18 years old primarily with autism. AWWA will require the generosity of donors to help finance the building fund of S$1.2 mil. 

Please help to donate and support the cause!
column47:
Established in 1970, AWWA is a local non-profit organisation that provides community-based programmes and services to people of all ages. From early intervention programmes to special education for children and youth with special needs and multiple disabilities, caregivers support, life-enhancing services for families to senior community home, rehabilitation and outreach programmes and services to enable ageing-in-place and active-ageing, AWWA puts people first. Through our programmes and services, we strive to empower and optimise the potential of our clients to lead dignified and independent lives. 

Visit us at awwa.org.sg to find out more about services and programmes.

Shan You's Community Meals Service aims to provide balanced and nutritious meals to our elderly beneficiaries. We offer three meals a day from Mondays to Fridays, and breakfast and lunch on Saturdays. We encourage our elderly to have meaningful interaction with one another which helps to reduce the impact of loneliness by having their meals in the community. Our free meals service also serves as a solution to ensure vulnerable elderly who are either unable to or have low motivation to cook for themselves to have proper meals.

Our free meals service is made possible by our kind donors and sponsors. We are currently seeking sponsorship for our daily lunches. Your sponsorship will go toward providing nutritious meals for our vulnerable elderly who do not have easy access to food in their daily lives.
column47:
Shan You is a non-profit social service agency set up in 1995 to provide professional counselling and social care services based on the guiding values of compassion, mindfulness, morality, and wisdom. Our services are available to all in the community, regardless of race, religion and ability to pay. 
  
Shan You is a registered society and a charity with the status of Institutions of a Public Character (IPCs). Shan You is a full member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS). 

With your monetary support, we will be able to continue to serve the community and our beneficiaries, building towards a caring and more resilient society!

A Mother's love is beyond our understanding. It is made of devotion, sacrifice, and sometimes pain. It knows no limits. It is unselfish and enduring. It is patient and forgiving. It never fails and falters. It believes beyond believing, even when the world thinks otherwise. 

This Mother's Day, join us in celebrating mothers who believe in the infinite possibilities of the child. Give a gift of hope on behalf of your mother. 

Proceeds from this campaign will go towards funding of DSA(S) programmes and services for persons with Down syndrome and their families.
column47:
Established in 1996, Down Syndrome Association (Singapore) is a primarily self-funded, non-profit social service organisation dedicated to serving the needs of individuals with Down syndrome and their families. Annually, DSA supports more than 400 persons with Down syndrome and over 1,000 family members. 

Our Mission
Develop individuals with Down syndrome through lifelong learning and social integration; support families through specialist services, information and education; and advocate for equal opportunities, quality of life and their contribution to society. 

Currently, DSA offers services in the following categories: Children Education Services, Adult Education Services, Enrichment Programmes, and Family Support Services.

column46:
Help us bring 1,000 disadvantaged children to spend Children's Day at S.E.A Aquarium and Maritime Experiential Museum in Resorts World Sentosa!

2019 marks the 11th edition of Children for Children (CFC), a community outreach and fundraising initiative.

Themed One Home, One Singapore, CFC 2019 is in celebration of Singapore's Bicentennial. The pupils of CHIJ (Kellock) Primary School will stage a special performance that celebrates the values of resilience and perseverance.

CFC is also a fundraiser for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) which fully sponsors the arts training of children and youth from low income families. Since 2005, BT BAF has reached out to more than 18,000 underprivileged children and youth.

We appeal to you to donate $300 per child to enable our children to spend a joyful Children's Day and also to aid BT BAF in supporting talented children and youth in the arts. Your donation is entitled to 250% tax deduction.

---

CFC is an annual community and fundraising event to bring underprivileged children to celebrate Children's Day at one of Singapore's iconic attractions. They also enjoy entertaining performances put up by their peers from CHIJ (Kellock) Primary School.

CFC is jointly organised by The Business Times, CHIJ (Kellock) Primary School and The RICE Company Ltd, a charity with IPC status.
column47:
The RICE Company Limited (TRCL) is a not-for-profit organisation and registered charity with IPC (Institutions of Public Character) status. 

TRCL seeks to harness the potential of the arts to benefit under-served children and youths in the community. TRCL manages a social fund (The Business Times Budding Artists Fund), arts centres (The Little Academy and 10 Square Youth) in Northpoint city and Orchard Central and two subsidiaries (Global Cultural Alliance and Millet Holdings). 

For more information, visit www.therice.sg

The number of children diagnosed with autism is on the rise in Singapore. In response to this increasing number, AWWA has embarked on a new project - the second AWWA School, to be ready in 2021, which will provide special education to 300 students aged 7 to 18 years old with moderate to severe autism. 

We have to raise over $1.2m for the second AWWA School so please support the building fund and help us continue our mission to empower the disadvantaged to maximize their potential to lead dignified and independent lives.

column3: Ground Up - help build a new theatre for our next generation

column46:
Esplanade is building a new waterfront theatre for our next generation. It will be a new theatre that brings together artists and audiences with new commissions and productions, especially works that speak of Singapore and Asian stories and viewpoints. It will also be a space for our young to feed their curiosities; a space for our seniors to gather; and a space where more can be done for the arts to lift the spirits of those in need. 

We are building this new theatre from the ground up and everyone can play a part. A $10 donation will go a long way in helping us to build this space that will bring our future generations of artists and audiences together.

With the waterfront theatre's Founding Donor, Bowen Enterprises Pte Ltd pledging to match the donations dollar for dollar, up to $50,000, we hope to raise a total of $100,000 through Ground Up to help build Esplanade's newest venue.

Esplanade is a charity and not-for-profit organisation and your support helps carry us forward in our next stage as a performing arts centre for everyone. 

Find out more at www.esplanade.com/thenextstage
column47:
Esplanade is Singapore's national performing arts centre and a not-for-profit organisation with a social mission.

We believe that the arts can transform lives through its ability to uplift spirits, provide inspiration, foster bonds and cultivate understanding. The arts can bring individuals and communities closer together and it is our vision to be a performing arts centre for everyone.

Esplanade operated by The Esplanade Co Ltd (TECL), which is a not-for-profit organisation, a registered Charity and an Institution of a Public Character. The Charity Council awarded TECL the Charity Governance Award (Special Commendation for Clarity of Strategy) in 2016, and the Charity Transparency Award for four consecutive years since 2016.

In line with Singapore Bicentennial, Home Nursing Foundation (HNF) office staff, nurses and patients  were involved in the creation of a unique logo print for our Limited Edition HNF Bicentennial umbrellas as our heartfelt gift to you for your generous donation during the month of August.

The aim of this fundraising campaign is to shine the spotlight on our Rain or Shine Heroes, our nurses, who visit patients to assist in their recovery and recuperation at the comfort of their home daily, and to make it possible for us to continue providing timely care for our patients without adding to their financial burdens.

For contributions of $200 & above, you may choose to receive or gift a Limited Edition HNF Bicentennial umbrella*. Kindly enter your preference and contact details in this form via the link: https://bit.ly/2YdHqaF

*Limited to the first 200 donors only, for donations of $200 & above only.
column47:
Founded in 1976, Home Nursing Foundation is the oldest and most established charity organisation that provides home healthcare in Singapore. We deliver comprehensive care programmes that are dedicated to our patients, regardless of their income level. From nursing to medical care, to looking after patients' social well-being and other practical needs, we bring care and support into the homes of those in need.

We depend on the generosity of the public and organisations to provide funding to enable us to serve our patients. Our patients needs are our primary concern and your donation will go towards supporting the most needy of them. All donations to HNF qualify for 250% tax deduction.  All tax exemption receipts will be emailed, and hard copies are upon request only. For more information, please visit our website at www.hnf.org.sg

column3: Giving Tuesdays at Playeum for Children with Disabilities

column41: Will go towards Giving Tuesdays Programme  and to Playeum Ltd.
column46:
Giving Tuesdays is a weekly play-based programme that takes place every Tuesday afternoon for children with varying disabilities. 

Little is known on how play supports children with a disability in terms of the development of executive and 21st century skills. Understanding what children can do through play is a process of discovery and Giving Tuesdays provides the opportunity for further exploration and observation on this. 

The Centre remains open to all other children at the same time to promote the spirit and importance of inclusiveness. For children with varying disabilities and their families, admission is supported by donations and the doors are open free for them. 

Currently, we have over 10 families who come regularly for the programme where they engage in different forms of artful play - painting, role-playing, tinkering and more. Through different activities, they have been able to express their creative potential, develop crucial skills such as communication and collaboration, and form new meaningful relationships. 

Giving Tuesdays has now become a weekly activity that they look forward to where they enjoy dedicated playtime with their family members and new friends, for the two hours or more that they are here for. We are also witnessing how parents of these families are gradually forming a community, as they interact and share relatable experiences. 

We are seeking for more donations to support more families to be part of Giving Tuesdays.
column47:
Playeum is an independent charity organisation (IPC) that champions children through play, creativity and the arts. We advocate for children's voices and the development of crucial 21st century skills such as problem-solving, communication, collaboration, critical thinking and more, through the play and the arts. 

Through our deep-impact programmes and outreach that enhance social-emotional learning and confidence building, we work closely with children under our community partners such as Family Service Centres (FSCs), Children's Home & Child Protection Services, and as well as children with special needs to ensure that all children have the space and time to play creatively. 

Find out more about our work at https://www.playeum.com/.

column46:
Project RESOLUTE: Research to improve diagnosis and treatments for Cancers of the Colon, Rectum, Liver, Stomach, Pancreas, Bile duct and Neuroendocrine.

Cancers affecting the digestive tract are the commonest cancers in Singapore - more than 3,500 Singaporeans are diagnosed yearly. Over the last 2 decades, research has resulted in improved diagnostic tests, treatment methods and clinical outcomes for patients. Still, more needs to be done!

We are medical oncologists from National Cancer Centre Singapore who take care of patients with gut cancers. We also do research with leading edge technologies to comprehensively study patients' tumors in order to develop new diagnostic tests and innovative treatments to control or eradicate the cancers. Through research, we can help our patients receive the right drugs at the right time and "translate" important science discoveries to benefit our patients.

We have raised $60,000 so far, thanks to your support but there is still much research work to do! $415,000 is needed annually to conduct this research ($1.25million over 3 years) which will help our team address some of the most pressing needs of our patients. Help us improve care and provide better quality of life through our research. Your support will move us closer towards a cure for these cancers!
column47:
Established in 2005, the NCC Research Fund supports innovative research to find the breakthroughs that will change how we understand, diagnose, treat and ultimately cure cancer.

With cancer research and care under one roof at the National Cancer Centre Singapore, the knowledge gained from patient-centric research fuels advancement in clinical care, which in turn provides knowledge that drives research. We firmly believe that today's research will pave the way for tomorrow's cure for cancer. 

Please note that in the event that the donations made for a specific purpose/project:
(i) Are less than the minimum  $10,000 to support an existing project OR
(ii) Has no new applicable project after a 2-year waiting period, the NCC Research Fund Board of Trustees reserves the right to channel these donations to the Fund's general pool in support of other worthy research projects.

Please note that donations must be made before 15 December for processing and be included in time for tax assessment in the same year.

column46:
PEACE-Connect Cluster Support currently operates a suite of seven (7) eldercare programs that are approved and partially funded by the Ministry of Health. These eldercare programs provide Social, Medical and Psychological support for seniors living in the Rochor, Kallang or Novena areas.

After 24 years in operation, PEACE-Connect Cluster Support now cares for over 2500 seniors. More than ninety percent (90%) of the seniors we serve live in public rental housing, have little income, and with minimal or no family help. A sample of the eldercare programs we run for the seniors includes free breakfasts and teas, subsidised lunches, nursing support, home help, counselling, medication reminders and physical rehabilitation. Feel free to contact us, and we will be more than happy to provide more in-depth information on these eldercare programs and how you can be involved.

With your kind financial giving and/or volunteering, we will be able to continue to run these eldercare programs without fail. We deeply appreciate your valuable contribution and time.
column47:
Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS), is a work produced by FAITH, an endurance nurtured by HOPE, and a labour prompted by LOVE. The early 1950s marked the genesis of SACS, with the setting up of a clinic by Mrs. Francis Thomas, a nurse and the wife of the Principal of St. Andrew's School. The clinic was to serve villagers living in the Potong Pasir area. 

In 1967, the Anglican Welfare Council - renamed Singapore Anglican Welfare Council (SAWC) in 1977 - was inaugurated to serve the needs of the community. SAWC was restructured to bring together the other community service arm of the Anglican Church in Singapore, and was renamed Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS) in 2004.

Presently, SACS is a voluntary welfare organisation and an approved Institution of Public Character. SACS serves the community through our care services in three areas: Psychiatric Services, Senior Services as well as Family and Children Services.

column46:
In order for the Singapore Association for the Deaf to continue to serve and work towards improving the quality of life of our Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community.

Come join us in for annual event, the "Deafinitely Durian" feast and help us raise funds for the Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community in Singapore. You and your family can enjoy durians including Mao Shan Wang as well as other seasonal fresh fruits, all for a good cause.

Date: 7 September 2019, Saturday
Venue: SADeaf
Corporate bookings: $2,000 (max 8 persons)
Individual (Adult) : $150
Child (below 12 years old) : $50
Time: 7.00pm - 8.00pm

SADeaf is a charity with an Institution of a Public Character (IPC) status and all donations are eligible for tax-deductible relief of 2.5 times of the amount donated.

We look forward to your support. Please do not hesitate to contact our Manager, Fundraising & Volunteer Management, Ms Tan Li Zhen at 6344 8274 ext 23 or email lizhen@sadeaf.org.sg for any queries.
column47:
The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) is a social service organisation that has been serving the Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community in Singapore for the past six decades. 

Established in 1955, SADeaf serves over 6,000 (FY19/20) Deaf and Hard-of-hearing persons. A member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and, is also supported by the Community Chest of Singapore, Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF). Internationally, SADeaf is affiliated to the World Federation of the Deaf (WFD) and locally to the Children Charities Association (CCA).

SADeaf mission is to assist the Deaf and hard-of-hearing persons to achieve a better quality of life and to enable them to integrate and contribute to society.

It costs SADeaf approx. $5.1 million per year to run all its services and programmes and is dependent on the bulk of its funding on the generosity of corporate and the general public.

Mystique, DSA(S) Charity Gala Dinner, is an opportunity for all to celebrate another year of milestones with our members, parents, donors and staff where our persons with Down syndrome will showcase their multi-talented abilities through the performances. 

This year, the 13th edition of DSA(S) Charity Gala Dinner - Mystique XIII, will be held on Saturday, 5 October 2019, at Shangri-La Hotel, Tower Ballroom. We are honoured to have Mr Teo Chee Hean, Senior Minister and Coordinating Minister for National Security, to grace the event as our Guest-of-Honour.

Look out for a new change in this year dinner as Radio DJ Glenn Ong will be joining The Flying Dutchman as our hosts for the evening. The theme - Leave No One Behind - highlights the importance for everyone to come together, embrace differences and walk along with our persons with Down syndrome towards an inclusive society!

column46:
Beyond the traditional stage, Sing'theatre is committed to making music and theatre universally accessible, especially in hospitals, reaching out in particular to the most isolated and underprivileged patients. 

It's been 7 years now that Sing'theatre is bringing Live Music to several hospitals, through 4 different projects. MusicFest @ SGH was the first, then we deployed our expertise @ NUH, for adults and also a very special programme for Kids, and finally @ TTSH 2 years ago.
Over the span of 7 years, we have reached more than 56,000 audiences, involved 1,000 volunteers, put on stage 1662 performers and provided 530 hours of Music. 
Now we are ready to move forward, and thanks to the support of SingHealth, we have been able to design this unique and ambitious project: 365 Days of Music @SingHealth. The aim is to bring 1-hour of live music everyday in 1 institution from SingHealth. 

WE NEED YOU TO MAKE IT REAL! The main goal of our fundraising campaign is to reach a sufficient budget to implement this project 365 days a year.

Indeed, music is the key ingredient to keep the blues away, and your donation will help to illuminate the day of patients, families, staff and visitors, in the hospital.

For more information about our community outreach hospital, click the below link to find out more: https://singtheatre.com/community-outreach
column47:
Sing'theatre is a non-profit professional theatre company. Sing'theatre recognised as an Institution of Public Character. Our mission is to be a creative platform that uses music and theatre to help shape an inspiring future.

Our motto is PERFORMING FOR A BETTER SOCIETY by:

1. Producing musical revues and shows that open social dialogues in the Singaporean community and promote multicultural interaction

2. Making music and theatre universally accessible, especially in hospitals, reaching out in particular to the most isolated and underprivileged patients

3. Empowering youth and the community as a whole by sharing our passion for performing and providing top-level musical theatre training

column46:
Dementia is known as The Long Goodbye. Elderly suffering from this brain disease lose their personalities and memories, long before they pass away. For their loved ones, it is a protracted period of loss.

In Singapore, 1 in 10 above the age of 60 suffer from dementia. By the age of 80, this rises to 1 in 3. 

Dementia, which has no cure, requires Singapore to try new and bold approaches.

One of these is using therapy animals.

In this new programme, elderly with dementia strengthen their emotional and mental well-being through activities with therapy animals, which are themselves rescued, unwanted, injured. 

In medical lingo, this is known as the provision of psycho-social care. 

In simpler terms, it is about giving the elderly the opportunity to love and care again, a role that these elderly have played their entire lives. 

When elderly are engaged like that, many other benefits fall into place naturally - they start speaking, joking, standing, walking, working their arm muscles. Their eyes sparkle again.

Although similar programmes exist overseas and validated by research (Stanford University, University of Pittsburgh, etc), the idea is new to Singapore. 

Thus, we are hoping to find supporters who want to accompany us on this journey into an unknown, yet important, area.

EQUAL is a charity and Institution of Public Character. Donations to us receive 250% in tax deduction.
column47:
"The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated."
- Gandhi

Hello, we are EQUAL, a young Charity with IPC status. 

We believe animals make people better. 

Every year, we strengthen the mental health of 1,500 people with special needs, youth, families and elderly, through giving them the opportunity to care for and work with rescued therapy animals.

In other words, we rescue animals who go on to rescue us.

Our therapy horses and cats may not look the prettiest from the outside, but they are so beautiful inside.

Working alongside them as our partners, our team of certified professionals help our beneficiaries develop social-emotional skills such as managing impulsivity, compassion, responsibility, and confidence via an Animal-Assisted Learning curriculum.

These skills help our beneficiaries succeed in school, employment and life.

Such skills are vital, yet they are difficult to teach.

That's where EQUAL comes in. Animals help us connect with our inner w

The Singapore Jump Fest 2019 aims to raise funds to set up the Kampong Siglap Life Skills Training & Retreat Centre (KSLTRC) for our beneficiaries, the low income and homeless individuals and families in Singapore.

KSLTRC is a center for effective and sustained engagement with our beneficiaries. Here, our beneficiaries will acquire mindset changes and essential life skills through meaningful interactions with
professional counselors, befrienders and mentors from the community.

Give to a worthy cause and have an amazing, health-boosting, fat-busting, energy elevating, "feel-good" jumping fitness workout. 
www.singaporejumpfest.com

Let us join hands to empower needy individuals and families to bounce back higher when life knocks them. Together we can eradicate homelessness in Singapore.
column47:
New Hope Community Services (NHCS) was registered as a charity in 2004. Our sole motivation is the love of God and the conviction that His church must stay relevant to the needs of the community. We are concerned for those in need and we strive to reach out to them, regardless of their race or religion.  We recognise that homelessness can strike in many ways. Our mission is to stand in the gap and provide a Shelter of Hope to these homeless Singaporeans and to empower them to alleviate and improve their situation. At New Hope Community Services, our goal goes beyond providing temporary shelter to those we serve; we want to infuse them with real hope to see their lives changed.

Our Mission: Restoring HOPE to displaced families and individuals.

Please visit our website www.newhopecs.org.sg or facebook page for more information.

column46:
The EtonHouse Community Fund, an Institution of Public Character (IPC) charity, to raise funds for children from underprivileged backgrounds in Singapore. The Community Fund is committed to helping these underprivileged children to change their lives through education. All proceeds will go towards benefitting these underprivileged children.

The ECF has over the years championed causes that have benefited children and youth in unfortunate circumstances. Working together with the Early Childhood Development Agency, the EtonHouse
Community Fund has helped to provide resources for 7 KidSTART playgroup sites for low-income families with 8 more sites in the pipeline to be rolled out in 2019. 

In August 2018, the EtonHouse Community Fund also launched a Play Library for the underprivileged children to promote healthy child
development and maintain strong parent-child bonding through play. The ECF 'box of joy' initiative that has completed 3 successful years has reached out to more than 3000 children in Singapore. It has also reached out to 164 children through their baby bonus account to
further their education.
column47: The EtonHouse Community Fund (ECF) was founded on the EtonHouse Group's strong belief in the importance of education and the spirit of giving back to society. Every child regardless of his or her background should have access to good quality education.

column37: To support our cause for the purchase of the medical equipment, providing quality, highly subsidised dialysis treatment to needy kidney patients
column38: To support our cause for the purchase of the medical equipment, providing quality, highly subsidised dialysis treatment to needy kidney patients
column39: To sponsor a dialysis chair, providing comfort for 6 kidney patients who spend more than 624 hours a year on a dialysis chair to sustain their lives.
column40: To sponsor a dialysis machine and give Life and Hope to 6 needy kidney patients who are on dialysis thrice weekly and 4 hours each session.
column41: Every drop in the ocean counts, your contribution means a lot to us!
column46:
I am Siew Hoon and I am 45 years old this year. Life had never been easy as I had to raise my daughter on my own after my divorce in 1994. It was really emotionally and physically draining to juggle between work and raising my daughter, Mandy. She was only 10 years old when I was diagnosed with glaucoma. By the time Mandy turned 12, I was completely blind. During that same year, my world came crashing down as I was also struck down with kidney failure. All I see now is darkness with an image of Mandy frozen at that age. 
You know, it can be very stressful and suffocating having to care for my child and also worrying about my dialysis fees. I am really thankful for the financial help that NKF has given me to sustain my life on dialysis for the past 12 years. I am just so thankful for every single day that I am given. I can spend time with the people I love. This is very important to me as it keeps me going. I look forward to the day when I can hold Mandy's child in my arms and enjoy my time as a grandmother. 

As kidney failure is on the rise, more and more kidney patients like me need your help as it is very tough for us to walk this journey on our own.

Your support means a lot to us!

- Koh Siew Hoon 

Your support through this meaningful campaign will give many more patients like Mdm Koh Siew Hoon a chance to lead fulfilling lives and face the future with hope. Please donate now!
column47:
The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) is currently supporting more than 5,000 kidney failure patients, about two-thirds of the national kidney failure patient population. Our patients are of the lower income group. Treating a patient costs over $2,000 a month, however, the treatment our patients receive is highly subsidised, with 74% paying $50 or less a month out-of-pocket. 

NKF remains committed to journeying with our patients every step of the way in their treatment and rehabilitative care, advocating kidney health to prevent kidney failure and making a difference in the renal landscape to benefit the community. 

Partner us in giving Life & Hope to our patients now!

All donations received through Giving.sg will be channelled to NKF General Fund, which will be used to provide subsidised dialysis treatment and holistic care for our patients. 

To view our financial statements, please visit our corporate website at https://nkfs.org/about-us/annual-reports/

column47:
Brahm Centre's mission is to Promote Happier & Healthier Living to counter mental and physical health challenges. 

Our Vision is to Empower Every Individual To Create Her/His Own Happiness

We provide support and assistance to seniors, befriending services, counselling services and an Assistline to support parents and students who are in distress. We also offer academic coaching to students. 

We offer health talks, music & movement and physio- gym sessions, therapeutic yoga, art coures and excursions.

Our signature programs are Mindfulness Foundation Course, Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction course , Mindfulness Based Cognitive Therapy course and Mindfulness Retreats.

HRnetLoves is a joint CSR initiative by HRnetGroup. We focus on creating  event platforms that will allow us to make a difference to local communities. The objective is to help move them a little closer to living a better life via these outreach activities.  

We are working with New Hope Community Services. They focus on providing services to improve the lives of the homeless and the low income families in Singapore.

Together with the New Hope team, we will be creating a fun and interactive carnival for the beneficiaries to participate in. With food carts, game stations, job fair booths and ration distribution, there will be something for everyone! On top of that, we will also be painting a section of the shelter to spruce up the environment that will be used by the beneficiaries.

column46: We operate 7 clinics over Singapore up to 30 September 2019 before the opening of our 8th clinic at Tampines, our 40 physicians service more than 1,000 patients a day.  With the proposed new clinic, we will be above to serve people staying/working at the East side of Singapore, especially the residents at Tampines.
column47:
SBFC provides subsidized health care services for the sick and needy. We operate eight TCM clinics in Singapore with about 40 certified practitioners of Traditional Chinese Medicine. Our employees comprising mainly clinic assistants, clerks and administrative staff, provide services and support to our patients. Our patients received 290 thousand times of free consultation during latest year. Our estimated annual operating cost is about $7.5 million fully supported by public donations/government grants. We have TCM Cancer Treatment Centre at the Main Clinic, Sembawang and Tampines Branch. In addition, SBFC also provides Counselling Services at the Main Clinic, Tanjong Pagar and Tampines Branch, taking care of the emotional and psychological well-being of the public.

Our regular fundraising activities, such as Fun Fair, Flag Day and Walkathon, were cancelled being affected by the COVID-19 pandemic. We earnestly appeal everyone to donate generously, in the spirit of fraternal friendship to support our free TCM

column46:
Riding for the Disabled Association of Singapore (RDA) is the only local charity with a designated Centre which provides therapeutic horse-riding program for persons with disabilities, 100% FREE OF CHARGE. Over the years, more than 7,000 persons with disabilities benefited from our program, improving the quality of life of the beneficiaries and their families.

We are piloting a new Equine-Assisted Activities Program
The new interactive non-riding based Program would mostly be performed next to, not on top of, the horse - the sessions would include a number of beneficial equine activities such as observing, handling, grooming, groundwork, and structured challenging exercises focused on the beneficiary's needs and goals. The new Program would benefited persons with disabilities, in particularly  those currently not served (e.g. beneficiaries above the weight limit or medically not suitable for riding) under RDA existing Therapeutic Horse-Riding Program.

We are targeting to raise an additional $250,000 to fund our new Equine-Assisted Activities Program and the planned expansion of our Therapeutic Horse-Riding Program. Your support will in many ways, help to give hope and transform lives of persons with disabilities. Thank you.


For enquiry, please contact us: Tel: 62500176 or email: mail@rdasingapore.org.sg
column47:
INSPIRING HOPE & IMPROVING LIVES OF PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES

Riding for the Disabled Association of Singapore is the only local charity which provides Therapeutic Horse-Riding and Equine-Assisted Activities for children and adults with disabilities, 100% free of charge.

Our therapy horses and ponies provide a tool for the purpose of contributing positively to the cognitive, physical, emotional and social well-being of individuals with special needs, in a non-clinical setting, that is fun and effective, helping the beneficiaries to function better in school/at work, at home and general daily activities, and ultimately helping to improve the quality of life for the beneficiaries and their families. 

As part of the therapy, we bring our riders out for walks at a nearby forested trail. For many of our riders with physical disabilities, going into a forest is impossible on a wheelchair or with a walking aid. But they can do so with ease on a horse-back. 
 
Over the years, some of our riders have advanced beyon

column46:
Super Typhoon Hagibis slammed into Japan on Saturday, 12 October, with heavy rain causing landslides and dozens of rivers to burst their banks. As of 17 October, the death toll has risen to 77, 186 injured and 14 still missing and the figure is expected to continue rising. More than 37,000 households are still without power, and 133,000 homes have no water.

Together with a local NGO, Mercy Relief will be conducting emergency hot meal distributions to the affected communities of Miyagi & Fukushima and we call for an urgent appeal for donations to reach our initial crowdfunding goal of $30,000 to bring the much needed aid to the affected communities.

Disasters show no mercy but you can. Donate now.

*Donations for foreign purposes are NOT eligible for tax-deductions.

Photo credits: (Reuters/soezeyatun), (EPA/Jiji press),  (AP Photo/Jae C.Hong)
column47:
Headquartered in Singapore, Mercy Relief was established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in the Asia Pacific. Today, we are Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency with dedicated leadership, capacity building expertise and an affiliate network operating across the entire disaster management cycle.

Mercy Relief provides emergency aid within 72 hours of an international appeal in the aftermath of a disaster. The objective of our longer-term sustainable development programmes is to uplift and empower communities in five key areas: water & sanitation, shelter, sustainable livelihoods, healthcare and education. For the past 17 years, Mercy Relief has responded to more than 86 human tragedies with more than $44.6 million in relief across 26 countries. We have implemented more than 72 post disaster projects and impacted over 2.6 million lives. 

Find more information about how Mercy Relief is transforming lives across Asia at www.mercyrelief.org.

SuperNature is proud to support KK Women's and Children's Hospital (KKH), Singapore's main women's and pediatric hospital. Children heal better when they are less stressed. Your generous donations will provide play, art and music therapy to the young patients at KKH.

All donations received will go towards supporting Kidz Horizon Appeal in aid of KKH Health Fund's Child Life Therapy (Part of SingHealth Fund, UEN 201624016E).
column47:
Because every woman and child deserves good health...
 
"Motherhood and childhood are entitled to special care and assistance." (United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights)
 
Here at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, we believe that every woman and child deserves good health. The KKH Health Fund (KKHHF) raises funds to help needy patients, who very often have exhausted all options and are in need of financial assistance, for their medical expenses. The fund also supports education, research and disease prevention programmes targeted at improving women's and children's health.

As KKHHF is totally dependent on donations, on behalf of the patients, we thank the generous donors who have literally saved lives by enabling the fund to continue with its work of giving financial support to needy patients.

You can be a part of this life-saving cause; we appeal to you for your kind and generous support*.

*All donations received are managed by SingHealth Fund (SHF), an institution of Public Character (UEN

In support of the Giving Week movement and the giving season, we invite you to be a supporting partner for ISEAS - Yusof Ishak Institute's flagship event, Regional Outlook Forum (ROF) 2020, held on 9 January 2020. 

In commemoration with #SGBicentennial, ISEAS - Yusof Ishak Institute's shared reflection of Singapore's unique DNA help supports the myriad of research and events that generate the interest of our heritage, and chart our way for the future to come. 

Your generous contributions to ISEAS - Yusof Ishak Institute will multiply the impact together with the Bicentennial Community Fund (BCF), building resiliency for generations of Singaporeans in the future.

Together, let's build a #CityofGood - a Singapore that Cares!
column47:
Our events and activities, research and general projects are made possible through the generosity of ISEAS donors and institutional partners, under ISEAS Research Funds.  

Formerly Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, ISEAS's work has been deeply relevant to policymakers, business leaders, government organisations and the scholarly community. On a regional level, we are attentive to ASEAN integration, regional geopolitics, economic, social and cultural issues. On a country-level, we focus on Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and Myanmar.

We invite you to support ISEAS as we continue to create a positive impact on Southeast Asia and the world.

For more information on the full scope of work, visit www.iseas.edu.sg

column46:
I'm Yuogan and I'm born Deaf. I'm 21 years old this year. My mother was killed in a tragic car accident and my father had no means and ability to take care of me due to his physical and mental health conditions, hence I've been staying at a Boy's Home for as long as I can remember. 

I'm thankful to The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) and my teachers in Deaf school for not giving up on me. Instead, they've inspired me to stay strong and study hard so that I can one day actualise my dream of being the first Deaf person to succeed in the air-condition and refrigeration industry. With support from SADeaf and the school, my life has been transformed. However, there are many Deaf children that need assistance. Many Deaf and their family need the right opportunity to shine. 

Please donate generously to empower and inspire future generations in the Deaf and hard-of-hearing community so that they too can see light at the end of the tunnel and lead meaningful lives like me. Your sustained giving can help them regain their footing and integrate with society. Click on the video to find out more.

Please visit our website for other forms of donation: sadeaf.org.sg/donate
column47:
The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) is a social service organisation that has been serving the Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community in Singapore for the past six decades. 

Established in 1955, SADeaf serves over 6,000 (FY19/20) Deaf and Hard-of-hearing persons. A member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and, is also supported by the Community Chest of Singapore, Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF). Internationally, SADeaf is affiliated to the World Federation of the Deaf (WFD) and locally to the Children Charities Association (CCA).

SADeaf mission is to assist the Deaf and hard-of-hearing persons to achieve a better quality of life and to enable them to integrate and contribute to society.

It costs SADeaf approx. $5.1 million per year to run all its services and programmes and is dependent on the bulk of its funding on the generosity of corporate and the general public.

column46:
Shan You is a social service agency that has been serving the community in Singapore for over 24 years, providing professional counselling and social care services based on the guiding values of compassion, mindfulness, morality, and wisdom.  Our services are available to all in the community, regardless of race, religion and ability to pay.

Today, Shan You Wellness Community serves more than 300 elderly and continue to provide a gamut of programme with our core focus in advocating mental wellness in our community such as:

-Behavioural Health Consultation Service that addresses the biopsychosocial needs of service users with chronic diseases
-Public Education for educational health and mental health talk and workshop provide to the public (patients, caregivers, primary care personnel)
-Day Activities and more than 20,000 healthy free meals are given out yearly
-Food Rations to low-income families, needy elderly and disadvantaged communities to enhance their physical, emotional, social and spiritual lives.  The service benefits more than 5,000 recipients yearly.

As most of our services are provided free to segments in our community and in order for Shan You to continue to serve and work towards improving the quality life of the elderly community as part of our annual Month of Giving drive, we are appealing for your generous support towards our cause especially during this festive season to lessen the daily challenges of living for them.
column47:
Shan You is a non-profit social service agency set up in 1995 to provide professional counselling and social care services based on the guiding values of compassion, mindfulness, morality, and wisdom. Our services are available to all in the community, regardless of race, religion and ability to pay. 
  
Shan You is a registered society and a charity with the status of Institutions of a Public Character (IPCs). Shan You is a full member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS). 

With your monetary support, we will be able to continue to serve the community and our beneficiaries, building towards a caring and more resilient society!

column46:
Imagine going without a bath in humid Singapore for a week, a month or even a year? This is the reality facing some bed-bound elderly, for whom having a warm bath daily at home is an impossible and luxurious task. Many of these elderly can only receive sponge or powder bath or wipe-down cleaning due to the constraints faced by their caregivers.

For Mdm Tan, 75, who injured her spine after a fall four years ago, the injury greatly impacted her mobility. Having no children of their own, Mdm Tan's husband is her sole caregiver. Even though Mdm Tan weighs 28kg, her husband is unable to carry her to the bathroom to shower her. 

This is where the GoodLife! HomeBathing team from Montfort Care comes into the picture. The team now helps to bathe Mdm Tan on a bi-weekly basis. This arrangement has brought her some joy, and it provides some respite for her husband.

This home bathing service, not only provides cleaning for the elderly, but more important it brings comfort and restore the dignity of these individuals.  

Help us to raise the funds needed to provide our bed-bound elderly the HomeBathing service, by making a donation now!

To find out more on this service, please call 9815 7190.

column46:
To most children, items like hangers and rags are just everyday household objects.

But for two brothers, these were things to be feared.

The boys, aged four and six, were beaten daily with such items by their parents.

They both have global developmental delay and their parents thought this was the appropriate way to discipline their special needs boys.

But thanks to the intervention of Big Love Child Protection Specialist Centre, the two boys are now safer.

A social worker from Big Love, which is a programme by charity Montfort Care, stepped in for 10 months to educate the parents on positive ways of parenting the siblings by home-based coaching.

Your support empowers us to make a positive difference to children with child protection issues, please give generously!

Thank you for supporting our work.

Support the Love of Books With Singapore Book Council!

Share the love of reading and stories with the Singapore Book Council (SBC) this Christmas! SBC is the longest-running independent charity in Singapore that aids writers, translators and illustrators in honing their craft.

We celebrated the 10th anniversary of our flagship festival, the Asian Festival of Children's Content (AFCC), this year. Your donation this holiday season will enable us to continue our festival and to support the people behind your child's picture books and stories.

With a donation of $50 or more, you will receive a token of appreciation consisting of the following:

1 limited copy of 'Islands of Creativity: Indonesian Children's Literature Today' 
1 limited copy of  'Skyscrapers, Books and Imagination: The Evolving Children's Literature Landscape in Singapore. 
1 Asian Festival of Children's Content (AFCC) tote bag.

When you've made your donation, please send us the following details to us at info@bookcouncil.sg
1. Your name
2. Best contact number
3. Email address
5. Pick up date and time, or if shipping is required (please note there will be additional costs for shipping).

Pick-ups can be done from 01/01/2020 to 01/02/2020, Monday to Friday (10am to 6pm) at our office, 90 Goodman Road, Block E #03-32 Singapore 439053.

Please note we will need this information to process your order as giving.sg does not provide this to us. We thank you for your generosity in supporting local stories.
column47:
The Singapore Book Council (SBC) is an independent charity with IPC status. Established in 1968 to support Singapore authors and literature, SBC aims to Build Our Imagine-nation by developing creativity, imagination, original thought and empathy. We focus on creative writing, translation, illustration, storytelling and reading. We are committed to developing the literary arts sector through our festivals, training workshops and courses, as well as book awards to recognise excellence. 

Because it all starts with a story. 

VISION: International recognition for quality, diverse Singapore literature.

MISSION: To develop, support and advocate a multicultural literary arts sector.

column46:
There may be many bursaries available for the physically disabled, but no Scholarships honouring their efforts in education. This Scholarship was founded in memory of the late The Honourable Justice Tan Ah Tah decades ago and to date, more than 400 students have been helped with more than $300,000 worth of scholarships. 

Two young ladies went to University because of this Scholarship Fund; one using the binoculars to decipher the lecturer's scribbles on the board, the other needing the magnifying glass to read the volumes of notes. Both were beneficiaries of SAWL's help through this scholarship. One graduated with a first class honours, the other with a 2nd Upper. Both are today working as research officers and contributing to the nation.

This is what the first class student has to say more than 10 years after receiving the scholarship: 'Without the worry of financial constraints, I was able to concentrate more on my studies and managed to do well. With the qualifications, I was able to get a stable job and am leading a happy life now.' The other, not content, with what she has already achieved pursued a masters degree, even though she has to read with a magnifying glass.

Join us to give hope to physically disabled students!
column47:
The SAWL Scholarship Fund was set up in 1987 to further the educational needs of needy students with physical disabilities who have displayed scholastic aptitude. In 2019, the Fund expanded its reach to include students with special needs, Autism Spectrum Disorder and intellectual disability. 

The Fund disbursed about $107,900 in 2019 to about 64 students. Since the inception of the Fund, more than 900 students have benefited from over $900,000 of scholarships disbursed to Secondary Schools, Institute of Technical Education, Junior Colleges and Tertiary institutions. 

The Fund continues to be well received by the community as there are almost no other scholarships available for these students which, unlike bursaries, also celebrates their academic achievements. 

The Fund is a registered Charity in Singapore and has an Institution of Public Character status (IPC).

Every child deserves a fulfilling childhood, special or not.

Metta PreSchool @Punggol specialises in early intervention programmes for children aged three to six from various races and religions who are diagnosed with mild to moderate autism spectrum disorders (ASD) and/or intellectual disabilities.


Early intervention can help infants and toddlers with delays catch up in their development.

It gives a child the support they need to make progress in life skills. Your kind donations will fund the programmes and services of Metta PreSchool for children with special needs.
column47:
All donations will be eligible for tax exemption and it will be included automatically in your tax assessment. Receipts will be mailed out for donations of $50 & above. For donations below $50, you may contact us at finance@metta.org.sg if you require a copy. As Metta sees the importance in saving the environment, we are gradually going paperless for our receipts to all donors with effect from 1 April 2021 onwards. We thank you for your understanding to walk this journey together to protect the environment that we live in. 

-----

Founded in 1992 by Venerable Chao Khun Fa Zhao, Metta Welfare Association was registered as a charity in 1994. Endorsed by the MSF, MOH and MOE, we are a member of the National Council of Social Service, Singapore Hospice Council and Singapore Disability Sports Council. 

Motto:
Compassionate love to share 
Brightens hope to those we care

Vision:
Inspired by the Great Compassionate Vows of The Medicine Buddha, we aim to provide social services for the community, regardless of race

column46:
Massive floods marked the first day of the new year in Jakarta after torrential rain pounded the capital and its nearby towns.

The floods with flow depth ranging from 0.2m-2.5m have caused power outages and road closures, as well as several localised landslides. The total number of deaths has climbed to 66 and is expected to continue rising. More than 18 million people are reported to be affected by this devastation with over 173,000  displaced and in urgent need of clean water, food, medical care and shelter. 

Together with a local NGO, Mercy Relief will commence our first phase of relief operations through the distribution of solar lights, hot meal & clean water to the affected communities in Jakarta Metropolitan Area. 

We call for an urgent appeal for donations to reach our initial crowdfunding goal of $50,000 to bring the much-needed aid to the affected communities.

Disasters show no mercy but you can. Donate now.

*Donations for foreign purposes are NOT eligible for tax-deductions.

Photo credits: (Reuters) / (Reuters) /  (AFP/Rezas) / (AP images)
column47:
Headquartered in Singapore, Mercy Relief was established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in the Asia Pacific. Today, we are Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency with dedicated leadership, capacity building expertise and an affiliate network operating across the entire disaster management cycle.

Mercy Relief provides emergency aid within 72 hours of an international appeal in the aftermath of a disaster. The objective of our longer-term sustainable development programmes is to uplift and empower communities in five key areas: water & sanitation, shelter, sustainable livelihoods, healthcare and education. For the past 17 years, Mercy Relief has responded to more than 86 human tragedies with more than $44.6 million in relief across 26 countries. We have implemented more than 72 post disaster projects and impacted over 2.6 million lives. 

Find more information about how Mercy Relief is transforming lives across Asia at www.mercyrelief.org.

column37: To support our cause for the purchase of the medical equipment, providing quality, highly subsidised dialysis treatment to needy kidney patients
column38: To support our cause for the purchase of the medical equipment, providing quality, highly subsidised dialysis treatment to needy kidney patients
column39: To sponsor a dialysis chair, providing comfort for 6 kidney patients who spend more than 624 hours a year on a dialysis chair to sustain their lives.
column40: To sponsor a dialysis machine and give Life and Hope to 6 needy kidney patients who are on dialysis thrice weekly and 4 hours each session.
column41: Every drop in the ocean counts, your contribution means a lot to us!
column46:
I am Siew Hoon and I am 46 years old this year. Life had never been easy as I had to raise my daughter on my own after my divorce in 1994. It was really emotionally and physically draining to juggle between work and raising my daughter, Mandy. She was only 10 years old when I was diagnosed with glaucoma. By the time Mandy turned 12, I was completely blind. During that same year, my world came crashing down as I was also struck down with kidney failure. All I see now is darkness with an image of Mandy frozen at that age. 
You know, it can be very stressful and suffocating having to care for my child and also worrying about my dialysis fees. I am really thankful for the financial help that NKF has given me to sustain my life on dialysis for the past 12 years. I am just so thankful for every single day that I am given. I can spend time with the people I love. This is very important to me as it keeps me going. I look forward to the day when I can hold Mandy's child in my arms and enjoy my time as a grandmother. 

As kidney failure is on the rise, more and more kidney patients like me need your help as it is very tough for us to walk this journey on our own.

Your support means a lot to us!

- Koh Siew Hoon 

Your support through this meaningful campaign will give many more patients like Mdm Koh Siew Hoon a chance to lead fulfilling lives and face the future with hope. Please donate now!
column47:
The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) is currently supporting more than 5,000 kidney failure patients, about two-thirds of the national kidney failure patient population. Our patients are of the lower income group. Treating a patient costs over $2,000 a month, however, the treatment our patients receive is highly subsidised, with 74% paying $50 or less a month out-of-pocket. 

NKF remains committed to journeying with our patients every step of the way in their treatment and rehabilitative care, advocating kidney health to prevent kidney failure and making a difference in the renal landscape to benefit the community. 

Partner us in giving Life & Hope to our patients now!

All donations received through Giving.sg will be channelled to NKF General Fund, which will be used to provide subsidised dialysis treatment and holistic care for our patients. 

To view our financial statements, please visit our corporate website at https://nkfs.org/about-us/annual-reports/

column46:
The Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) is devoted to exploring the rich artistic heritage of Asia, especially the ancestral cultures of Singaporeans. As a reflection of Singapore's rich and diverse communities and religions, the museum recently installed a permanent showcase of Sikh objects. This collection of important Sikh artefacts is a testament to the community's significance in the larger social fabric of Singapore.
 
ACM would like to thank the Central Sikh Gurdwara Board in Singapore for its donation of S$5,500 in support of this initiative to bridge awareness and appreciation of Sikh artefacts and culture.
 
To grow the museum's collection, ACM would like to seek your donation to acquire new artefacts of the Sikh religion for display at the museum's permanent galleries. Your donation will also be considered for a dollar-for-dollar matching by the Cultural Matching Fund, thus doubling the impact of the gift. The matching fund enables ACM to conduct research, create new knowledge and present exhibitions to the public. Your cash gift will be eligible for a 250% tax deduction in line with IRAS regulations.
 
For more information, please contact supportacm@nhb.gov.sg
column47:
The National Heritage Board's mission is to preserve and celebrate the shared heritage of our diverse communities, for the purpose of education, nation building and cultural understanding. It manages the national museums and heritage institutions, sets policies relating to heritage sites, national monuments, and the national collection. Through the national collection, NHB curates heritage programmes and presents exhibitions to connect the past, present, and future generations of Singapore. We need your support in order to grow and sustain our efforts in conserving our heritage and culture. 

For more information on the full scope of NHB's work, https://www.nhb.gov.sg/

Get updates by following us on https://www.facbook.com/NationalHeritageBoardSG/

Pride in our past, Legacy for our Future.

column46:
SportCares is grateful to filmmakers JianHao Tan & Ridhwan Azman for creating the short film, "Majid The Legend", as part of NVPC and Blue 3 Asia's 15 Shorts film anthology.

Inspired by the late Majid Ariff's life story, we can all agree that a good coach can change a game, but a great coach can change a life. 

Support SportCares as we look to #ChangingLivesThroughSport, combining positive sport experiences and nurturing sport coaching, to empower the vulnerable and the underserved in Singapore overcome barriers to a life of growth and confidence. 

Established in 2012, SportCares has reached out and engaged more than 36,000 low-income children, youth at-risk, vulnerable seniors and persons with disabilities through sport. 

Together, let's build a City of Good!  #15Shorts #CityofGood  #SGCares
column47:

Please go to One Team Singapore Campaign (www.giving.sg/vision2030/oneteamsingapore) or SportCares Campaign (https://www.giving.sg/vision2030/sportcares)  if you wish to donate to a specific cause.

column41: Will go towards the Play-It-Forward fund.
column46:
Playeum strives for a world of inclusiveness, where every child of any socio-economic background and ability can play side-by-side without fear of judgement through the PIF fund. 

Playeum works closely with community partners such as Family Service Centres (FSCs), Children's Home & Child Protection Services to ensure that children from marginalized backgrounds and as well as children with special needs have the space and time to play creatively. This is done through the support of the Play It Forward fund which supports all components of our hands-on STEAM programme for children and is free for our community partners. 

Through open-ended play, children become masters of their own worlds where creating, exploring, conquering fears, negotiating, making decisions and resolving conflicts become second nature. Providing this physical space empowers children and allows them to step forward to become contributing global citizens.
column47:
Playeum is an independent charity organisation (IPC) that champions children through play, creativity and the arts. We advocate for children's voices and the development of crucial 21st century skills such as problem-solving, communication, collaboration, critical thinking and more, through the play and the arts. 

Through our deep-impact programmes and outreach that enhance social-emotional learning and confidence building, we work closely with children under our community partners such as Family Service Centres (FSCs), Children's Home & Child Protection Services, and as well as children with special needs to ensure that all children have the space and time to play creatively. 

Find out more about our work at https://www.playeum.com/.

At SportCares, we use sport to change lives.

By nurturing confidence, building connections and cultivating care for all, including the vulnerable youth, families and seniors as well as the disabled and persons with special needs.

Your donation today will give a better tomorrow to the communities we serve.  On our part, we will continue to work hard to ensure that every bit that we receive will make a difference in their lives. 

All donations to SportCares above $10 will generate a tax credit of 2.5 times the original amount for the donor.

Equally important, if you know someone or a group that could do with a helping hand from SportCares, please reach out to us through sportcares@sport.gov.sg
