column46:
Nur, aged 6, is a new student at PPIS preschool and she is not alone. She is joined by her two younger siblings, who are also enrolled in the same school as both their parents are working. Unlike her peers, Nur entered school later due to COVID-19.

Her father, the sole breadwinner of the family, was retrenched from his job due to the pandemic. Trying to make ends meet, Nur's father took on a second job while her mother decided to return to the workforce to help support the family. They also re-located, and that is when Nur's parents chanced upon PPIS as an alternative childcare arrangement.

Nur's parents worked tirelessly to provide for their children, even as their savings depleted by the day. PPIS was deeply moved by their sheer grit and determination to carve out a better life for their family, and stepped in to provide the necessary support for Nur and her siblings. 

Today, through donations made to PPIS, Nur and her siblings get to learn and play with friends while their parents - including her mother who has successfully secured a permanent job - head out to work with peace of mind. More importantly, these children have equitable access to quality education and are empowered to realise their potential.

PPIS preschools offer a safe space for vulnerable children like Nur and her siblings. There is always light at the end of the tunnel, and we hope you can be the light in our children's eyes.

(Zakat contributions are not eligible for tax-deduction.)
column47:
PPIS (Singapore Muslim Women's Association) is a non-profit organisation dedicated to helping less-privileged women, children and families through holistic community programmes. We offer Family Services, Student Care and Early Childhood Education through 16 Centres islandwide.

Since 1952, we have helped 40,000 Muslim women, children and their families through services such as family therapy, fostering, early childhood education, afterschool care and training.

This year, we hope to raise funds of $1.21 million to continue to support women and their families!

column37: Our heartfelt thanks to you for supporting access to justice for all!
column38: Our heartfelt thanks to you for supporting access to justice for all!
column39: Our heartfelt thanks to you for supporting access to justice for all!
column41: Our heartfelt thanks to you for supporting access to justice for all!
column46:
Justice can mean different things to different people. Legal justice, in particular, is often unrelatable to most people unless they have experienced a brush with the law, whether personally or by loved ones. Oftentimes, the legal issues they face are accompanied or brought about by wider social issues, such as poverty, employment, education, and mental health. We believe that with better access to legal justice, we can level the playing field for the weak and vulnerable.
 
At Law Society Pro Bono Services (LSPBS), we aim to improve access to justice for all through legal awareness, advice, and advocacy.

Our programmes help protect and empower marginalized individuals through legal education and pro bono legal advice and representation. We also support Singapore community organisations (non-profit organisations, charities, social enterprises) with legal assistance and capacity building, helping them to help others.
 
LSPBS will only be able to sustain these programmes with your support. Every little bit helps.
 
All proceeds of this campaign will go towards LSPBS' operating and programme costs.
column47:
The law is a mystery for many. And intimidating. Especially if you can't afford legal advice.
 
Our lawyers give generously and selflessly of their time and expertise for the needy in our community - to help those who can't help themselves. Our lawyers also do pro bono work for nonprofit organisations, helping them to help others.
 
We are a Singapore registered Charity (UEN: 201700430E) and Institution of a Public Character, established to support our lawyers in the noble cause of serving the vulnerable and the marginalised with access to justice.

Help pregnant teenagers in need this Ramadan

Many young teens who turn to us for assistance come from low-income families. The unplanned pregnancy places immense financial and emotional stress on their families, exacerbating existing issues. Hence, for the month of Ramadan, Babes is raising funds to give all our beneficiaries and their loved ones household vouchers they can use to prepare and celebrate the festivities. 

Lend a helping hand and make a difference to bring some joy and respite to those in need. 

Excess funds would go towards supporting operational expenses.

Image credits: Taqirumi
column47: Babes Pregnancy Crisis Support Ltd offers support to pregnant teenagers by proactively providing information and community resources that facilitate responsible decision making. Babes believes that support from her family, friends and wider community is essential for a pregnant teenager to make her decision responsibly and for her to experience a sense of normalcy in this difficult period.

column3: Stand in Solidarity - Save Blood Cancer Patients Today #SGUnited #WeGiveinSolidarity
column37: Thank you for saving a life and standing in solidarity with patients and their loved ones.

column39: Thank you for saving a life and standing in solidarity with patients and their loved ones.
column40: Your $180 donation will enable ONE POTENTIAL MARROW DONOR to be added to the register and increase that unique chance of finding a match to a patient! Thank you for your thoughtful contribution
column41: Thank you for saving a life and standing in solidarity with patients and their loved ones.
column46:
Leukaemia and Lymphoma are blood-diseases that continue to strike any one at any time even during COVID-19. Very often, a bone marrow transplant will be their last chance of survival. 

URGENT bone marrow transplants must still take place. Patients with already weakened immunities cannot wait till a better time when the COVID pandemic is over to safely proceed. Their LIVES TODAY simply DEPEND ON this life-saving transplant.

Needy patients and their loved ones have a greater emotional burden and worry if they will still be able to get the financial subsidies needed for their bone marrow transplant and post-transplant recovery. (Transplant costs start from at least S$70,000).

Please let these patients and their loved ones know they are not forgotten in times of crisis with a kind donation to BMDP from the Solidarity Payment we have all received.

Giving.SG is lending their support too with no admin fees charged during this period. YES! That means 100% of your donation will aid the cause!

Let us unite and save lives together! #SGUnited #WeGiveinSolidarity
column47:
Blood diseases such as Leukaemia, Lymphoma and Myeloma can strike any one at any time. When all other treatment has failed, a bone marrow transplant is their only chance of survival.

When patients are unable to find a matching donor within their family, they come to us in search of a Matched Unrelated Donor (MUD), who could give them a second chance at life. As finding a MUD means a healthy donor with the same DNA profile, the odds of finding that unique match is very low.

Thus since 1993, we at the Bone Marrow Donor Programme (BMDP) are committed to building and managing Singapore's only register of volunteer marrow donors. Providing hope for patients suffering from blood-related diseases.

For more information, please visit www.bmdp.org

UEN: S93SS0141J / IPC: HEF0015/G

column46:
Let Us Transform The Lives Of Our Children Through The Arts

Launched in 2005, The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) originated from a conviction that no child with strong interest and potential in the arts should be denied the opportunity to develop his or her talents due to a lack of financial resources.

The Fund reaches out to financially disadvantaged children and youth from six to 19 years old where they receive fully sponsored arts training at The Little Arts Academy and 10 Square Youth. The training provides opportunities for the beneficiaries to explore and nurture their interest and talents in music, dance, theatre, visual arts and technology. Over the years, the children and youth have grown in confidence and resilience through their journey in the arts. We are  heartened by the research conducted by Kantar Consulting in 2019 that showed a strong impact of the arts training on our beneficiaries' socio-emotional development and aspirations (baf.sg/impact-of-bt-baf/).

We hope you may open your hearts to support our children and youth so that they may continue to pursue their artistic talents and achieve their aspirations.  All donations qualify for 2.5 times tax deduction.

Do visit our website and Facebook for more information about our outreach and programmes as well as the performances and artworks of our beneficiaries.

www.baf.sg , facebook.com/littleartsacademy/ , facebook.com/10SquareYouth/
column47:
The RICE Company Limited (TRCL) is a not-for-profit organisation and registered charity with IPC (Institutions of Public Character) status. 

TRCL seeks to harness the potential of the arts to benefit under-served children and youths in the community. TRCL manages a social fund (The Business Times Budding Artists Fund), arts centres (The Little Academy and 10 Square Youth) in Northpoint city and Orchard Central and two subsidiaries (Global Cultural Alliance and Millet Holdings). 

For more information, visit www.therice.sg

Foundation of Rotary Clubs (Singapore) Ltd is the umbrella body that unites the 22 Rotary Clubs in Singapore and is the charity arm of Rotary in Singapore. Over the past 24 years, the Foundation has transformed gifts into impactful service projects that changed lives in the community. 

Organised by the our member, Rotary Club of Kampong Gelam, proceeds will go towards the provision of dry goods, iftar meals and a variety of Eid, Hari Raya, traditional meals including lontong, rendang and kuah lodeh organised by BAPA in their annual effort to help 300 underprivileged families who have been registered with MUIS, Islamic Council of Singapore.

BAPA is a Religious and Educational League of Radin Mas. It is a non-profit organisation and has been at the global stage for humanitarian efforts in many parts of the world.
column47: FRCS is the umbrella body that unites the 23 Rotary Clubs in Singapore and is the charity arm of Rotary in Singapore. Over the past 24 years, the Foundation has transformed gifts into impactful service projects that changed lives in the community - bringing to fruition, the Rotarian ideal of "Service Above Self".  In so doing, promoting the core Rotarian values of Fellowship and Global Understanding; Ethics and Integrity; Diversity; Vocational Expertise, Service and Leadership within and beyond the Rotarian community.

As part of Together, Singapore Cares, an SG Cares-initiated campaign in support of National Day celebrations, support ISEAS Research in 2021 as we champion the Singapore Spirit in doing good for the community and bringing you the latest ISEAS research products and webinars!

From now till 31 Mar 2022, the impact of your giving is now DOUBLED! 

With every dollar matched from the Tote Board Enhanced Fund-raising Programme, the multiplier effect of your donations will continue to support ISEAS research products and webinars, designed to benefit ISEAS stakeholders and community of policymakers, business leaders, diplomats, scholars and the general public, which is made publicly available to all!

Your support will also strengthen the next generation of scholars and researchers under the Wang Gungwu Visiting Fellows Programme, through timely and relevant research on breaking events and challenges in the region.

For more information, please go to https://www.iseas.edu.sg/support/get-involved-with-iseas/

Let us stay united, and emerge stronger as a community together!

#NDP2021
#GivingWeekSG #SGCares #TheGivingStories #OurHeartforSG #CityofGood #CompanyofGood #EmergingStronger
column47:
Our events and activities, research and general projects are made possible through the generosity of ISEAS donors and institutional partners, under ISEAS Research Funds.  

Formerly Institute of Southeast Asian Studies, ISEAS's work has been deeply relevant to policymakers, business leaders, government organisations and the scholarly community. On a regional level, we are attentive to ASEAN integration, regional geopolitics, economic, social and cultural issues. On a country-level, we focus on Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Thailand and Myanmar.

We invite you to support ISEAS as we continue to create a positive impact on Southeast Asia and the world.

For more information on the full scope of work, visit www.iseas.edu.sg

12BR Singapore Company in response to the appeal from The Boys Brigade in Singapore Headquarters to raise fund for the relocation of our BB HQ to 10 Kwong Ave, decided to take this opportunity to adopt one of the rooms in honour and loving memory of our founding OC - The Late Mr Loo Kee Hian.

BB had always been an integral and important part of Mr Loo's life. He had dedicated and contributed much to the starting of 12BR Singapore Company from 1994. Just as BB has always been a part of Mr Loo, Mr Loo will always be a part of our 12BR history and legacy.
column47:
The Boys' Brigade (BB) was founded in Glasgow, Scotland, in 1883 as a uniformed youth organisation. Today, the movement has spread across the globe with over half a million members worldwide. 
 
The BB in Singapore was founded on 12 January 1930.  We employ a holistic approach in the development of youths. Through our programme, we hope for our youths to be world-ready, with the passion to act on their dreams and to serve and care for the community.

Boys and Youths discover more about themselves, overcome challenges and broaden their perspectives through our exciting outdoor adventure activities, meaningful community projects and enrichment programmes. Increasingly, the emphasis is on leadership development, team building, life skills, adventure activities and community service.

The BB members' experiential learning journey takes place in three specially designed programmes, namely Juniors Programme (Primary Schools), Seniors Programme (Secondary Schools) and Primers Programme (Polys, JCs and ITEs).

column46:
A Thanksgiving Gift for the New BB Headquarters at 10 Kwong Avenue

This year, 2nd Singapore Company celebrates our 90th Anniversary (1931 to 2021). It's no small achievement to reach this important milestone. Today, 2nd Coy continues to be one of the strongest and most vibrant BB companies in Singapore with 80 Officers and Boys. Our Company has also won the Best Company Award for 4 consecutive years (2017, 2018, 2019, 2020).  The theme for our 90th Anniversary is "Anchored by Hope for 90 years".

Also for this year, our Brigade Headquarters will be moving to a new location at 10 Kwong Avenue and is embarking on a fundraising exercise, and have appealed to all BB companies for financial support. 2nd Coy has taken on the challenge to support the Brigade Headquarters Relocation Project. We are therefore inviting all old Boys of 2nd Coy to come together to help raise a sum of $25,000 towards the new BBHQ Building Fund. An Appreciation Plaque will be displayed outside the room that we have adopted.

We are looking for 200 old Boys to each donate $125 to raise the amount of $25,000.  We hope to raise this sum within the next 3 months. We are also aware that some of you might be prepared to donate a larger sum, hence please do indicate your donation accordingly. 

Do note that all donations will enjoy a tax deduction of 2.5 times.  Thank you for your generous support and donations!

column46:
Playeum runs high-touch STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts and Math) programmes for at-risk children. Playeum's specially crafted STEAM workshops incorporate it's very own pedagogy and aims to help at-risk children with low academic achievements increase their confidence levels, resilience, skills, innovation as well as their social and emotional learning.

With these intervention programmes tailored to children from at-risk backgrounds, Playeum looks to break the cycles that hold them back by striving for long term impact and inspiring children to take charge of their own circumstances and be able to meet their fullest potential. Through open-ended play, children become masters of their own worlds, where creating, exploring, conquering fears, negotiating, making decisions and resolving conflicts become second nature.

The programme includes learning to code, applying coding on Sphero robots, and using morse code and spin art kids to explore connections. One of the participants, Aniq said, "I get bored in school because all the teachers try to make us become more interested in the topic by talking, but if the teaching method could be more like this, we will be keen to learn". When asked what else he learned at this week at the workshop, he shared, "I learned to help other people that are in need."

Support Playeum's high touch STEAM programmes. For corporate sponsors who would like to support the programme in more detail, contact share@playeum.com.
column47:
Playeum is an independent charity organisation (IPC) that champions children through play, creativity and the arts. We advocate for children's voices and the development of crucial 21st century skills such as problem-solving, communication, collaboration, critical thinking and more, through the play and the arts. 

Through our deep-impact programmes and outreach that enhance social-emotional learning and confidence building, we work closely with children under our community partners such as Family Service Centres (FSCs), Children's Home & Child Protection Services, and as well as children with special needs to ensure that all children have the space and time to play creatively. 

Find out more about our work at https://www.playeum.com/.

column46:
Ms Siti (not her real name) was in the midst of an emotionally draining divorce and suffered from breast cancer during her pregnancy. We got to know of her case when she was trying to make ends meet and stepped in to assist her household and her children's necessities. She has since given birth, is recovering from her illness and much more stable at the moment. 

As the project name suggests, we aspire to be that helping hand on our clients' road to recovery and tread the journey with them until they can stand on their feet.

Sponsored by Baring Private Equity Asia and its staff members, Project Journey With You is a targeted fundraising administrative plan for Jurong Central. The first run of the project will reach out to 400 households in Jurong Central's rental estate with interim assistance packages. Each set will include $15 Ezlink Card and $25 NTUC Voucher. The modalities of support will be varied, and will evolve with time.
column47:
Loving Heart Multi-Service Centre (Jurong) is a non-profit voluntary welfare organisation started in 2004 and now serve the residents and community of Jurong, Bukit Batok and Yuhua.

Situated at Block 316 Jurong East Street 32, #01-279, Loving Heart undertakes social projects, collaborate with relevant social agencies and organisations to better serve the community, and promote bonding among residents in the neighbourhood.

*Registered as a society in 2004 (ROS-0163/2004 WEL), LHMSCJ is a member of the National Council of Social Services (NCSS) and has been granted charitable status since November 2004.

column46:
Make this upcoming Father's Day celebration a special and meaningful one to remember by supporting Alzheimer's Disease Association's (ADA) Father's Day Charity Cookies Fundraiser!

Many of us know someone who has been impacted by dementia. Pledge your support towards a Dementia-Inclusive Society with ADA's freshly baked cookies.

Donate $75 and receive two bottles of home-baked cookies (Chocolate Chip flavour and White Chocolate flavour) and a limited-edition ADA Tote Bag (while stocks last).

*All our cookies are lovingly made by our Muslim vendor.
*Self-collection of the cookies will be made at ADA HQ office. We will provide the information once the donation is received.

Proceeds will help ADA provide immediate resources and support for Persons Living With Dementia and Caregivers impacted by the pandemic, and to bolster ADA's vital outreach programmes and services, as well as our operations.

Mr Peter Lim has been diagnosed with dementia for a decade, but with the support of those around him, he does not allow this condition to define him. Dementia is not a battle to be fought alone. Take action now and make a difference to Persons Living With Dementia and their caregivers.
column47:
Alzheimer's Disease Association (ADA) was formed in 1990 as a result of a growing concern for the needs of persons with dementia, their families and caregivers. 

Through our work, the Association hopes to reduce stigma by increasing awareness and understanding of dementia, enabling and involving persons living with dementia to be integrated and accepted in the community, and leading in the quality of dementia care services which support persons with dementia and their families. 

As a non-profit organisation, ADA operates with limited resources. We cannot battle dementia alone. Donation will help fund our programmes and services that will benefit our beneficiaries and their families.

column46:
CAS provides help & assistance to groups, individuals and organisations that need emergency and long term medical help for their animals.

Often the victims of hit and run accidents, fights or abuse - many of these street dogs and cat required life-saving, emergency treatment.

There also the dogs and cats that need long term help with problems such as kidney failure, heart conditions, cancer and much more. Many of these animals have had hard lives thought ill-treatment, malnutrition and have been abandoned - but they still have so much love to give.

We spend on average $18,000 per month of CAS rescue cases, and another $18,000 per month on long term medical needs.

Please help us help them.
column47:
Causes for Animals (Singapore) Limited (CAS) is an animal welfare charity set up and registered in 2013 to support the needs of local animal welfare in Singapore. CAS employs programmes and policies to promote best practice with involve ethical, sustainable and compassionate treatment of these animals.

Our current adoption  centre  houses up to 50 rescued dogs to be rehabilitated for rehoming. CAS has a no-kill policy of animals placed in our care. Animals are given optimal care and decisions on medical treatment rely upon vet advice. Medical assistance is also provided to injured dogs rescued by third parties. Shelter operational costs, veterinary services and medical supplies average $30,000 month.

CAS relies mainly on public donations for funding.

column46:
Give with Liberty is our company-wide employee charitable giving programme. This year, we have chosen to partner Care Corner Singapore Ltd, to provide support in their Mental Health and Counselling services.
 
Mental health is one of the areas that has increasing need as many individuals may have lost financial stability during the pandemic. Care Corner's Mental Health and Counselling Service offers outreach initiatives, content development for engagement and professional counselling services at affordable rate to help individuals cope with their emotional distress and life challenges. The funds raised will be used to support individuals in these areas of work.

In the last one year, Care Corner's Mental Health and Counselling Services Group has reached out to more than 5,000 youths, answered 13,000 distress calls though their counselling hotline and conducted more than 4,000 counselling sessions, mostly at a subsidized rate. Care Corner desires their clients to have healthy minds and beautiful lives.
 
We invite you to join us in bringing care and giving back to our community in this campaign which ends June 15, 2021. When we each give a little, together we make a big difference in all our communities.
column47:
Established since 1981, Care Corner Singapore is a non-profit organisation that has multiple service points island-wide. For more than 40 years, the organisation has been serving the isolated and disadvantaged in Singapore through our extensive services, such as helping families in need, youths at-risk, special needs children, children from low-income families, seniors and counselling needs.

It is our vision to provide Care to every corner in Singapore, to reach out to the vulnerable and needy in spite of all the constraints and uncertainties. Your generous donation will support families that are struggling to meet their daily needs, children with learning challenges, individuals with mental health challenges, and youths-at-risk especially during this difficult time. Everyone can do their part to extend a helping hand by donating generously to help the community we serve.

column46:
Amidst this Phase 2 (HA), our at-risk children will face difficulties at home keeping themselves well, both physically & emotionally, and meaningfully occupied.  #ENGAGE 3.0 aims to reach out to 250 disadvantaged kids aged 6-12 years, from low-income families. Through this initiative, we will be able to provide them with meals and craft packs twice a week over this June school holidays.

Tasty meals will include hamburger and spaghetti to keep the children happy and hungry-free.

Fun craft packs such as making pencil and handphone holder with ice-cream sticks will not only keep them meaningfully occupied but create items that are useful for them.  Other craft works use cardboards to create items to thank our frontliners such as character and message boxes to show gratitude to them.  The completed craft works will be posted on FB and IG to showcase their creativity and share their messages to the frontliners.

We hope you may open up your hearts and support #ENGAGE 3.0 so that together we can continue to take care of our at-risk children to keep them safe and well during this difficult period.

All donations will be eligible to 2.5 times tax deduction.
column47:
The RICE Company Limited (TRCL) is a not-for-profit organisation and registered charity with IPC (Institutions of Public Character) status. 

TRCL seeks to harness the potential of the arts to benefit under-served children and youths in the community. TRCL manages a social fund (The Business Times Budding Artists Fund), arts centres (The Little Academy and 10 Square Youth) in Northpoint city and Orchard Central and two subsidiaries (Global Cultural Alliance and Millet Holdings). 

For more information, visit www.therice.sg

column46: 'Living Legacies - Lessons for the future generations' is commissioned by Xin Yuan Community Care.  It is a collection of inspirational life lessons related by the seniors, which serves as valuable depository for future generations.  In fact, it comprises a collection of twelve feature stories of our elderly members and contribution articles from our partners.  Xin Yuan will be printing 3,000 copies of this softcover book by the third quarter of 2021 which will be distributed to schools, libraries and our partners.  We are looking for partners in this meaningful project and to bring a difference to our beneficiaries.
column47:
Xin Yuan Community Care (XYCC), set up in May 2005, is a registered member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and is also an Institution of Public Character (IPC). Our charity is committed to providing regular financial assistance and other forms of therapeutic, health, and educational support to 200 needy elderly as well as 50 underprivileged children from low-income families in the Bishan-Toa Payoh area. 

We do so by providing daily group exercise activities for our elderly led by our fitness trainer. We also provide the space and opportunity for our elderly to interact with each other, or with volunteers, which also provides social and emotional support. In addition, XYCC provides financial support to needy families, giving them monthly grocery supplies and subsidies.

We also ensure that we hold festive celebrations such as Chinese New Year, Hari Raya, Lantern Festival, Deepavali and Christmas for all our beneficiaries and their families.

column46:
This National Day, make a positive difference to the lives of those who need our support the most. Lend a helping hand to the dementia community and continue to stay united in the journey ahead as one people and nation.

Did you know dementia is not a part of normal aging?

Dementia is a neurodegenerative condition that causes progressive cognitive decline, leading to increasing difficulties in coping with everyday activities. The condition affects the brain, causing brain cells to die at a faster rate than normal. As a result, the cognitive capabilities of the person with dementia declines. 

While the signs, symptoms & behaviours of dementia may vary from person to person, some common characteristics are failing memory, deterioration of intellectual function, & personality changes. Whilst there is no cure for dementia yet, engaging persons living with dementia with activities & customised therapies to interests, also known as using the Person-Centred Care approach can help keep their minds stimulated, & may help to slow down & delay the progression of the condition.

Your donation will go a long way to enable ADA to support persons impacted by dementia and caregivers. Be sure to hashtag #NDP2021

column46:
Project F.I.N. (Families-In-Need) focuses on helping distressed families to cope better through our wide range of services particularly during this crisis. While some are facing family issues, others may have lost their jobs. We have a holistic approach to these issues  providing financial assistance to tide them over their immediate needs (utilities, rental, school fees), basic necessities, guidance and support to strengthen family bonds, counselling & addressing other social issues they may be facing.  
We invite you in this act of giving to touch these lives to give them hope for a brighter tomorrow.  Your valuable support will help us to enhance our programmes, provide better services and assistance to our beneficiaries. 

Our beneficiary's testimony (Social Support)
Mdm L suffers from depression, anxiety disorder and insomia. Her husband was in the halfway house and she was all alone at home with no family support. Mdm L lost her part-time job and had not been successful in sourcing for another job. Her savings was depleting and she felt extremely insecure and lost. She was worried about her daily living expenses and the Covid-19 situation further aggravated her condition. FaithActs provided her with groceries and household items to tide her through. Subsequently, her husband was granted an early release and she was relieved as she could now have support with her husband. They seek out to work as general cleaners and FaithActs continue to encourage and counsel her.
column47:
FaithActs is a non-profit community care service agency serving the needs of children, youths, families, and seniors in Singapore since 2004. We aim to positively impact, change, and transform the lives of those around us through the provision of programmes and services which meet community needs and alleviate social problems regardless of one's ethnic, socio-economic, and religious backgrounds. By focusing on the strengths and potential of each individual, we hope to equip and empower them to take steps in makes changes in their lives.

With your valuable support, FaithActs will continue to grow from strength to strength, providing love, care and support for the community.

The story of Dylan is a testimony of our youth who joined our after school programme at Primary 5. Dylan developed skills in public speaking and took on leadership roles with voluntary opportunities.  Today, Dylan is a 28 year old business owner.

column37: Thank you for showing kindness to our young children and youths in need to enrich their lives in their journey of learning

column46:
The video is a testimony of our youths learning journey. We believe that each child should have every opportunity to attain their full potential. We are committed to ensure that they are able to build a strong foundation in literacy and numeracy.  Our aim is to help our kids develop holistically in the areas such as of (A)cademic, (C)reativity, (T)raits and (S)hared values (ACTS). We encourage them to learn and grow according to their strengths, interest and personalities.  FaithActs creates a positive learning experience through group-based workshops and hands-on activities, making them confident and be lifelong learners to continue exploring their worth regardless of life circumstances.  

FaithActs is committed to help enrich and empower the lives of the kids living in our community. Your generous donation will help them in their life's journey towards building a better future.

Child's story from The Learning Hub
I am a latchkey kid and I am fortunate to be given an opportunity to go the Learning hub, an after school programme to meet FaithActs staff during weekdays. My mother is unable to coach me in my studies as she does not know English. My two older siblings does not play with me as they are already grown up and I am often left alone at home. At FaithActs, I get to learn with peers my age. I made improvements with help from my tutors and all the enrichment classes I attended at the Learning Hub.

Thank you  for making a difference!

column46:
Cycle for Good brings together individuals, families and friends to cycle and raise awareness on the importance of combating social isolation and building a more inclusive community for seniors and PWDs.

Today, there are approximately 21,000 seniors in the community who have little or no social support. There are also close to 32,000 persons aged 15-64 with physical or mental challenges who have limited options for socialisation to boost their mental well-being. With your support, CWA aims to raise awareness and funds to broaden our reach and deepen our impact on the community.

Your participation and donations in Cycle for Good will help CWA meet its goal of raising $200,000 to engage 600 new beneficiaries and  train 100 new volunteers by the end of 2021.
column47:
Why support Cycling Without Age Singapore?

 Our vision is a world in which no senior faces social isolation, and has the opportunity to feel the wind in their hair.

Our mission is to give seniors the chance to feel a part of society. We give them the right to wind in their hair, the right to experience the city and nature close up from the bicycle and the opportunity to tell their stories in the environment where they have lived their lives. 

We build bridges between generations and reinforce trust, respect and the social glue in our society.
 
Thank you for helping us to bring freedom, joy and smiles to the seniors of Singapore.

column46:
2021 marks the 25th anniversary of St Luke's Hospital. In 1996, the hospital was started to meet a need - that of the elderly sick. Since then, the hospital has played a pivotal role in transforming community care, and grown in the strength of its core services spanning rehabilitation, dementia, wound, palliative care and outpatient services. 

Each year, we care for 2,000 inpatients and 3,000 outpatients, regardless of race, language or religion. Over the years, our multi-disciplinary healthcare team has looked after close to 50,000 inpatients and outpatients.

To celebrate this significant milestone, we are launching a campaign themed "Celebrating Silver", which carries a key message to raise awareness on staying healthy and ageing well in one's silver years.

The campaign will culminate in a virtual fundraising event on 15 October 2021, 8.30pm where we will launch a short film and a virtual book that encapsulate "25 stories above 65" - celebrating 25 inspiring individuals aged 65 above, ageing well and making a positive impact in the community. Minister for Health, Mr Ong Ye Kung is our Guest-of-Honour for the event. 

All donations, big or small, will go a long way towards fostering an inclusive society that celebrates our silver generation, empowering them to age well and live better.

For more information or event RSVP, visit https://slh.org.sg/gosilver/silver-screen/

#SGCares #GivingWeekSG #CityOfGood
column47:
St Luke's Hospital, named after the patron saint of the medical profession, was the first hospital in Singapore dedicated to the elderly sick.

We have expanded our services beyond the elderly to enrich more lives. An Institution of a Public Character, we care for 2,000 inpatients and 3,000 outpatients each year, regardless of race, language or religion. As illnesses may be long and chronic, we care holistically for patients' physical, emotional and psychosocial well-being.

Impactful and innovative in transforming community care, we were the first recipient of the President's Award for Social Impact (2012), and the first community hospital to receive the National Healthcare Innovation and Productivity Medal (National University Hospital - St Luke's Hospital Integrated Care Path, 2016). We topped the Community Hospital Patient Experience Survey in 2018.

Follow us at fb.com/slhsg

In celebration of Singapore's 56th birthday, NCCS hopes to rally the Singapore community to get up on your feet and exercise to show support for a cancer-free nation! 

We would like to invite YOU to join this celebration with a 56-minutes online yoga session! 

Simply make a minimum donation of $28 and we will send you a unique zoom link via email.

Date: 7 August 2021 (Saturday)
Time: 9am
Location: Zoom

Let us do our part to stay active and do good at the same time!

Please note:
- Feel free to use your yoga mat if you have one, but fret not if you do not. The yoga class can be conducted without the use of yoga mat/props, so anyone can join in. 
- To receive the unique zoom link in a timely manner, please make your donation and include your email address, by 5 August 2021. Thank you for your understanding. 


All donations will go towards NCCS Cancer Fund and aid in cancer research, patient care, cancer education and areas of greatest need.
column47:
Someone in Singapore is diagnosed with cancer every hour. For many, a cancer diagnosis is an emotional and difficult time. The NCCS Cancer Fund helps support the fight against cancer by supporting patient care, cancer research and cancer education. 30% of funds will be used to cover operating expenses.

NCCS helps over 26,000 cancer patients each year. From the moment they are diagnosed and throughout their treatment we are with them, providing the very best care, by the best people, in the best place.

Donate today and help us give hope to people with cancer.


All donations received are managed by SingHealth Fund (SHF), an institution of Public Character (UEN 201624016E).
All donors are required to provide their Tax Reference number (e.g. NRIC/FIN/UEN where applicable) to enjoy tax deduction. The donation will be automatically included in the donor's IRAS tax assessment. As such, we will not be sending any official receipt, unless upon written request by the donor.

column46:
Adults on the autism spectrum can thrive in employment.  But they need help.

It has been proven that with training and support, many people on the autism spectrum can work.

Individuals on the autism spectrum have strengths and abilities like you.  When matched to the right jobs, and with training and support, they can be productive contributors to society. 

Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) (ARC) runs a structured programme under its Employability and Employment Centre (E2C) to enable adults on the spectrum to be trained, gain and keep employment.

However, not everyone may be suitable for work. Not every employer is able to scope or redesign jobs that fit the strength of individuals on the spectrum.  Some will benefit from specially scoped jobs or work models that are not available in the open job markets.

ARC creates some of these jobs and income opportunities through its social enterprises, The Art Faculty and Professor Brawn, as well as other ongoing and new initiatives. 

The current pandemic has impacted all of us. Job market conditions have weakened.  Dine-in restrictions and semi-lockdowns have resulted in a sharp drop in the footfall and businesses of our social enterprises.

Please help us sustain our programmes and services.
Thank you for caring and making a difference in transforming lives!
column47:
ABOUT US
Autism Resource Centre (Singapore) or ARC is a not-for-profit charity based in Singapore.  Registered in 2000, it was started by professional and parent volunteers dedicated to serving children and adults on the autism spectrum to help these individuals lead meaningful and independent lives in society.

OUR PROGRAMMES 
To ensure individuals on the autism spectrum realise their maximum potential with the support of their caregivers and professional team, ARC provides a wide range of core services.

ARC started Pathlight School, the first autism-focused school in Singapore offering a unique blend of mainstream academics and life skills for primary and secondary students.

Other signature programmes include early intervention, training for professionals and caregivers, employability and employment services, enrichment programmes and library and information services.

ARC also operates two social enterprises, The Art Faculty and Professor Brawn, to create and provide more job opportunities for individual

column46:
Hello - thank you for vising our fund-raising campaign. We are EQUAL, a non-profit organisation that strengthens the emotional and mental well-being of people in need, using therapy horses and cats (dogs too, soon) that have themselves been rescued and given a second shot at life.

We are a team with a diverse crew of animal-assisted intervention professionals who are former MOE teachers, social workers, counsellors, animal trainers and jockeys. 

In EQUAL, we serve beneficiaries comprising youths, people with special needs, families, and the elderly.

Through an Animal-assisted learning curriculum, EQUAL help people facing challenges open up to create changes in mindsets and behaviours that are deep and long-lasting; learning social-emotional skill sets that are important but conventionally hard to teach. This work is new to Singapore but Animal-assisted Learning and Therapy is well-established in Europe, North America, South America and Oceania with decades of proven outcomes.

To do our work, EQUAL relies heavily on support from the public, as government funding typically covers only a percentage of the costs of charities.

In order to continue this beautiful cycle of helping animals to help us, we hope you'll join us on this adopting journey to adopt our equine partners, spreading the word about our Animal-assisted Learning programs that have empowered our beneficiaries to find a sense of purpose and identity.
column47:
"The greatness of a nation and its moral progress can be judged by the way its animals are treated."
- Gandhi

Hello, we are EQUAL, a young Charity with IPC status. 

We believe animals make people better. 

Every year, we strengthen the mental health of 1,500 people with special needs, youth, families and elderly, through giving them the opportunity to care for and work with rescued therapy animals.

In other words, we rescue animals who go on to rescue us.

Our therapy horses and cats may not look the prettiest from the outside, but they are so beautiful inside.

Working alongside them as our partners, our team of certified professionals help our beneficiaries develop social-emotional skills such as managing impulsivity, compassion, responsibility, and confidence via an Animal-Assisted Learning curriculum.

These skills help our beneficiaries succeed in school, employment and life.

Such skills are vital, yet they are difficult to teach.

That's where EQUAL comes in. Animals help us connect with our inner w

column46:
#Burpees4SOSG - Do it for the Special needs community

Around the world, there's a misperception that people with intellectual disabilities can't do what others can. In our first-ever fitness challenge, we want to dispel negativity and rally the community to get active, and give a little show of support to persons with intellectual disabilities. 

At Special Olympics Singapore, we focus on the abilities, and not on their disabilities. We challenge you to perform as many burpees as you can in 30 secs, post a video, and hashtag #Burpee4SOSG. 

Take your support further by donating a minimum amount of $10 to our cause.  

All the funds raised will go into funding the sports trainings that we provide to our athletes with special needs to help them reach their fullest potential. 

Change lives, one burpee at a time!
column47: Special Olympics (SO) Singapore was set up in April 1983 as an adjunct committee of the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (MINDS) and the Association for Educationally Sub-Normal Children now known as Association for Persons with Special Needs (APSN). Subsequently, it was officially registered as an independent voluntary welfare organisation with the Registrar of Societies on 15 January 1991 and as a charity with the Commissioner of Charities on 22 February 1994. SO Singapore is affiliated to the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC). SO Singapore is recognised by Sport Singapore, formerly known as Singapore Sports Council, as a National Sports Association (NSA). SO Singapore is also a certified Institute of Public Character (IPC) organisation.

column46:
Did you know? The median amount to acquire a pair of hearing aids is approximately $3,000 and could easily go up to $15,000 if better features are required for work/education purposes as they enable clients to achieve better sensory input. Having a pair of hearing aids would assist them in receiving further education, securing more employment opportunities and having an overall better quality of life.

In addition, recurring cost of purchasing hearing aid batteries will also impact the long term financial stability of those using the hearing aid daily for long hours.

As a Voluntary Welfare Organization (VWO), The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) is heavily dependent on fund raising and the generous donations of corporates and the general public. At least $5.1 million is needed per year in order for SADeaf to effectively run all its services and programmes.

These services ranges from counselling, soft skill training, jobs opportunities, social integration activities, Singapore sign language training, deaf access services (Interpretation & Note taking) and many more. 

To ensure continuity and sustainability of these services, SADeaf requires the support of each and everyone throughout the year. 

Help us prepare and get ready to support those in need whenever the situation arises. 

Be a change maker, be a giver.
column47:
The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) is a social service organisation that has been serving the Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community in Singapore for the past six decades. 

Established in 1955, SADeaf serves over 6,000 (FY19/20) Deaf and Hard-of-hearing persons. A member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and, is also supported by the Community Chest of Singapore, Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF). Internationally, SADeaf is affiliated to the World Federation of the Deaf (WFD) and locally to the Children Charities Association (CCA).

SADeaf mission is to assist the Deaf and hard-of-hearing persons to achieve a better quality of life and to enable them to integrate and contribute to society.

It costs SADeaf approx. $5.1 million per year to run all its services and programmes and is dependent on the bulk of its funding on the generosity of corporate and the general public.

column46:
SNEC and SERI are inviting you to participate in the inaugural 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021'. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

I have severe dry eyes and endured sleepless nights from the burning sensation and pain in my eyes. The blurry images also affected my driving and I could not drive family around anymore. All these changed after I was introduced to plasma eyedrops. The pain is gone and I now can drive again. Most importantly, I started to sleep soundly every night. It has given me a new lease of life! 

Mr Ang (name changed to protect privacy) and many patients suffering from severe dry eyes were given a new lease of life, thanks to this new research innovation arising from the Ocular Surface Research Group in SERI.

Plasma from cord blood can be developed into eyedrops to treat severe dry eyes. This had improved the quality of our patients' lives. Further research will enable us to make personalized medicine, as further customization of useful anti-inflammatory proteins and growth factors in the eyedrops can be performed according to each patient's tear abnormality.  This example highlights the importance of translational research by SNEC and SERI. But research like this needs continuous philanthropic support to be able to develop future therapeutics for blinding eye diseases.
column47:
Launched in July 2016, VisionSave is a novel initiative that taps on philanthropic investment to usher in innovative eye care research, treatment and delivery in Singapore and the region. It also aims to save sight and ensure optimal outcome for every patient. 

VisionSave aligns with SNEC and SERI's reputation as a centre of eye care and research excellence in Singapore, as well as the philanthropic spirit of the late SNEC founder Professor Arthur Lim, who modelled a giving spirit in both his personal and professional endeavours.


For more information, please visit our websites: https://www.visionsave.sg and https://ww.snec.com.sg

column47:
Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS), is a work produced by FAITH, an endurance nurtured by HOPE, and a labour prompted by LOVE. The early 1950s marked the genesis of SACS, with the setting up of a clinic by Mrs. Francis Thomas, a nurse and the wife of the Principal of St. Andrew's School. The clinic was to serve villagers living in the Potong Pasir area. 

In 1967, the Anglican Welfare Council - renamed Singapore Anglican Welfare Council (SAWC) in 1977 - was inaugurated to serve the needs of the community. SAWC was restructured to bring together the other community service arm of the Anglican Church in Singapore, and was renamed Singapore Anglican Community Services (SACS) in 2004.

Presently, SACS is a voluntary welfare organisation and an approved Institution of Public Character. SACS serves the community through our care services in three areas: Psychiatric Services, Senior Services as well as Family and Children Services.

column46:
As we face the pandemic together, we hope to bring some joy to 1,000 underprivileged children to spend a day at Adventure Cove Waterpark!

Children for Children (CFC) is an annual community event that brings vulnerable children from 50 primary schools to an iconic attraction to enjoy Children's Day.  CFC also fundraises for The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF) that supports the training of disadvantaged children to develop their artistic talents and aspirations.

In lieu of the pandemic, CFC seeks to provide a pair of Adventure Cove Waterpark tickets to 1,000 underprivileged children to be accompanied by his/her parent or guardian to visit the attraction at their own time during the year-end holiday.  The tickets will be distributed on 7 Oct in celebration of Children's Day.

On the same day, a 10-min musical video titled 'Love Triumphs' will be launched on Youtube and Facebook to encourage all children in Singapore to support one another as we overcome the pandemic.  This video will be produced by students from CHIJ (Kellock) and beneficiaries of BT BAF.

We seek your kind support towards CFC 2021 to bring joy to 1,000 children on Children's Day. Your donation qualifies for 250% tax deduction. 

CFC is co-organised by The Business Times, CHIJ Kellock and TRCL.
column47:
The RICE Company Limited (TRCL) is a not-for-profit organisation and registered charity with IPC (Institutions of Public Character) status. 

TRCL seeks to harness the potential of the arts to benefit under-served children and youths in the community. TRCL manages a social fund (The Business Times Budding Artists Fund), arts centres (The Little Academy and 10 Square Youth) in Northpoint city and Orchard Central and two subsidiaries (Global Cultural Alliance and Millet Holdings). 

For more information, visit www.therice.sg

column46:
Living with kidney failure is a difficult path to walk alone.

How can we as a community do our part to help kidney failure patients in their courageous journey towards rehabilitation?

You can show your love by supporting Project 2000 to provide lifelines for our patients.

Through this project, we hope to raise $300,000 to provide new dialysis machines, which are critical in sustaining the lives of dialysis patients. Each machine can benefit 6 patients who are on dialysis 3 times a week, each time for about 4 hours.

Join us in gifting our patients a better tomorrow!

You can make a donation through Giving.sg or the following platforms:
1. Cheque 
Please make cheque payable to "NKF" and write your full name & NRIC/FIN/UEN on the back of the cheque and mail to:
Donor Relations - Project 2000
The National Kidney Foundation 
81 Kim Keat Road 
Singapore 328836    

2. Bank Transfer 
Name of Account: THE NATIONAL KIDNEY FOUNDATION A/C 1 
Account Number: 024-008491-4 
Name of Bank: DBS Ltd 
Branch Name: Toa Payoh 
SWIFT/IBAN/ABA Codes: DBSSSGSG

Thank you for giving Life and Hope to kidney patients!

#SGUNITED #NKFsg #GivingLifeandHope #Project2000
column47:
The National Kidney Foundation (NKF) is currently supporting more than 5,000 kidney failure patients, about two-thirds of the national kidney failure patient population. Our patients are of the lower income group. Treating a patient costs over $2,000 a month, however, the treatment our patients receive is highly subsidised, with 74% paying $50 or less a month out-of-pocket. 

NKF remains committed to journeying with our patients every step of the way in their treatment and rehabilitative care, advocating kidney health to prevent kidney failure and making a difference in the renal landscape to benefit the community. 

Partner us in giving Life & Hope to our patients now!

All donations received through Giving.sg will be channelled to NKF General Fund, which will be used to provide subsidised dialysis treatment and holistic care for our patients. 

To view our financial statements, please visit our corporate website at https://nkfs.org/about-us/annual-reports/

column46:
Every year, World Humanitarian Day (WHD) falls on the 19th of August. On this day, we commemorate all humanitarian workers for their resilience and sacrifice in the course of their work in serving others. With the recent COVID-19 pandemic, we would like to also honour all aid and health workers who continue, despite the odds, to provide life-saving support and protection to people most in need.

Donations collected from this years' WHD campaign will be directed to the Impact Fund where it will be used to scale our impact both locally and regionally and reach out to more communities in need. 

Mercy Relief continues to operate, supporting vulnerable communities affected by the pandemic. 
If you would like to find our work in COVID-19 Relief Aid and Assistance in Asia, you can go to mercyrelief.org/covid-19.

Don't have a giving.sg account? 
Go to our website to give by Paynow, Credit Card, Cheque
https://www.mercyrelief.org/donate/

If you have any other enquiries, write in to us at intouch@mercyrelief.org


Donations to our Impact Fund will enjoy a 250% tax exemption.

*NRIC number is required for donations to Impact Fund to generate tax-deductible receipts.
column47:
Headquartered in Singapore, Mercy Relief was established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in the Asia Pacific. Today, we are Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency with dedicated leadership, capacity building expertise and an affiliate network operating across the entire disaster management cycle.

Mercy Relief provides emergency aid within 72 hours of an international appeal in the aftermath of a disaster. The objective of our longer-term sustainable development programmes is to uplift and empower communities in five key areas: water & sanitation, shelter, sustainable livelihoods, healthcare and education. For the past 17 years, Mercy Relief has responded to more than 86 human tragedies with more than $44.6 million in relief across 26 countries. We have implemented more than 72 post disaster projects and impacted over 2.6 million lives. 

Find more information about how Mercy Relief is transforming lives across Asia at www.mercyrelief.org.

column46:
Eye Run Champion Prof Aung Tin:

I will be participating in the inaugural 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021' coming up on 1 October. The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

I am an eye doctor and a research scientist. I treat patients with glaucoma as well as research on this 'silent thief of sight'. Glaucoma is one of the top eye diseases linked to aging in Singapore. It causes 40% of blindness in Singapore .

I will be walking 200km in The Eye Run /Cycle to create awareness of this deadly and silent disease. I am hoping to raise $30,000 towards research & education. This will help to fight for sight.  I look forward to your support to help reach my donation target and to motivate me towards completing this target.
column47:
Launched in July 2016, VisionSave is a novel initiative that taps on philanthropic investment to usher in innovative eye care research, treatment and delivery in Singapore and the region. It also aims to save sight and ensure optimal outcome for every patient. 

VisionSave aligns with SNEC and SERI's reputation as a centre of eye care and research excellence in Singapore, as well as the philanthropic spirit of the late SNEC founder Professor Arthur Lim, who modelled a giving spirit in both his personal and professional endeavours.

Eye Run Champion CI A/Prof Doric Wong:

I am participating in the inaugural 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021' coming up on 1 October. The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

I am an eye doctor and also the Chief Risk Officer and deputy vice chair in Professionalism and Ethics. I am a retina surgeon taking care of patients with retina diseases. Age-related macular degeneration, a chronic retina disease, is fast becoming common among a rapidly ageing population in Singapore. 

I will be running 100km in The Eye Run /Cycle spread over October and November to support the work of SNEC in research and education. I am hoping to raise $8,000 towards this run for sight.

column46:
Did you know that there are an estimated 500,000 individuals who are deaf or hard-of-hearing in Singapore?

A survey conducted in 2017 indicated that 1 in 2 employers do not intend to hire deaf people. While attitudes are gradually changing, many in the hearing community do not understand the Deaf
community and may unknowingly be biased against them.

This is why the People with Disabilities (PwD) team in Accenture started DeafTember, a month of raising awareness, inclusion and acceptance for the Deaf Community. Activities such as sign language classes and silent trivial nights are held within the firm to educate and enlighten.

Internally within the firm, we are raising $10,000 through our silent trivial night to donate to SADeaf and we are hoping to raise another $10,000 to double the impact created.

This campaign is an Accenture effort to raise funds for SADeaf to continue its incredible efforts for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing by delivering sign language classes, ensuring access of interpreters and notetakers and providing health services to the community among others.

Here at Accenture, we care about diversity and inclusion. And It's time to let our hands do the talking.
column47:
The Singapore Association for the Deaf (SADeaf) is a social service organisation that has been serving the Deaf and Hard-of-hearing community in Singapore for the past six decades. 

Established in 1955, SADeaf serves over 6,000 (FY19/20) Deaf and Hard-of-hearing persons. A member of the National Council of Social Service (NCSS) and, is also supported by the Community Chest of Singapore, Ministry of Education (MOE) and the Ministry of Social and Family Development (MSF). Internationally, SADeaf is affiliated to the World Federation of the Deaf (WFD) and locally to the Children Charities Association (CCA).

SADeaf mission is to assist the Deaf and hard-of-hearing persons to achieve a better quality of life and to enable them to integrate and contribute to society.

It costs SADeaf approx. $5.1 million per year to run all its services and programmes and is dependent on the bulk of its funding on the generosity of corporate and the general public.

My son and I are participating in the inaugural 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021' coming up on 1 October. The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. column46:
This campaign is a collaboration between ONE FM 91.3 and Dementia Singapore.

As Singapore's leading Social Service Agency in specialised dementia care, Dementia Singapore provides support to improve the well-being of people impacted by dementia through Care innovation, Advocacy & Empowerment. While there is no cure for dementia, engaging persons with dementia with activities & therapies customised to their interests, also known as using the Person-Centred Care approach, can help keep their minds stimulated & help delay the progression of the condition.

Dementia Singapore manages the New Horizon Centres (Bukit Batok, Jurong Point, Tampines, Toa Payoh), which provide daycare services including occupational therapy, physiotherapy & social activities for people with dementia. The daycare centres also offer respite to caregivers & family members, enabling them to continue caring for their loved ones with dementia at home. 

Many of us may know someone who is impacted by dementia. Dementia is not a battle to be fought alone. With your help, we can do more for those impacted by this condition & make a difference to the dementia community. Every donation counts & will go a long way in helping us provide much comfort & encouragement to those in need.

A portion of the collections, not exceeding 30%, goes to ONE FM 91.3 for every dollar raised as part of this collaboration. 

ONE FM91.3 plays the greatest hits from 80s to present. Hear them live at www.onefm.sg/
column47:
Dementia Singapore was formed in 1990 as the 'Alzheimer's Disease Association' to better serve Singapore's growing dementia community, increase awareness about dementia, and reduce the stigma surrounding the condition.
 

As Singapore's leading Social Service Agency (SSA) in specialised dementia care, Dementia Singapore aims to advocate for the needs of people living with dementia and their families; empower the community through capability-building, knowledge and consultancy; and deliver quality, person-centred care innovations.

Dementia Singapore is registered as a company limited by guarantee UEN No. 202111519K.

column46:
Every year, junior lawyers join our charity to pursue pro bono legal service as a full time calling.  They represent needy and vulnerable individuals who are unable to afford lawyers in court through our schemes for criminal legal aid and other ad hoc pro bono services. Watch Pramnath's video on how support for the Fellowship has allowed him to make a drastic difference to his beneficiary's life!

The Fellowship Fund was founded to raise funds to engage junior lawyers to act for our beneficiaries in need of legal representation under our current and any future representation schemes, and will also cover their training and other related practice costs. 

This campaign will receive dollar-for-dollar matching under the Tote Board's Enhanced Fundraising Programme, subject to caps.
column47:
The law is a mystery for many. And intimidating. Especially if you can't afford legal advice.
 
Our lawyers give generously and selflessly of their time and expertise for the needy in our community - to help those who can't help themselves. Our lawyers also do pro bono work for nonprofit organisations, helping them to help others.
 
We are a Singapore registered Charity (UEN: 201700430E) and Institution of a Public Character, established to support our lawyers in the noble cause of serving the vulnerable and the marginalised with access to justice.

column46:
Since the pandemic hit our shores, it has been a challenging time for all especially the livelihood of our beneficiaries - the reformed offenders, their children and families. Through it all, we are grateful for the continuous support from donors and community partners to help sustain our outreach and assistance to these low-income families. 

In collaboration with the Asian Seniors Tour (AST), ISCOS ReGen Fund is happy to be one of the charities supported by the Charity Pro-Ams to be staged during the AST's Winter Season 2021!

Choose to play at the prestigious Singapore Island Country Club (SICC) on either one of these dates: 
6 Oct 2021 at SICC, Island Course
17 Nov 2021 at SICC, Bukit Course

Charity Donation Packages
- $10,000 to play one Pro-Am flight with golfing benefits and marketing mileage
- $20,000 to play two Pro-Am flights with golfing benefits and marketing mileage (plus one A-board on course sign with donor company's logo)
- $6,000 to sponsor one Amateur Golfer to play in Charity Pro-Am with a Professional Golfer of their choice
- $3,000 to sponsor one Amateur Golfer in Charity Pro-Am or a Professional Golfer to play in an AST tournament

Direct donations are welcomed too. Part of the proceeds will go towards IRF to support our cause and keep our work going - check out full details at www.irf.org.sg/Golf2021. For enquiry, please email us at marketing@iscos.org.sg.

It's time to gather your golf buddies to have fun while contributing to a good cause! THANK YOU!
column47:
The ISCOS ReGen Fund is a registered charity that supports children and families of reformed offenders as well as the reformed offenders in rebuilding their lives. The charity is an approved Institution of a Public Character (IPC) since 15 March 2019.

Through the Fairy Godparent Programme (FGP), various initiatives are rolled out to empower the children with the opportunity of a complete education and the skills required to be employable and financially independent in future. FGP is designed with the main objective of preventing intergenerational offending.

column47:
Established in 1995, LB has more than 25 years of experience in befriending and caring for seniors in order for them to age in place in the community. Over the years, LB strives to address the varied needs of more than 86,000 seniors by adopting a senior-centric approach in its eldercare services. Leveraging on the support of some 1,000 regular volunteers, we actively engage more than 6,000 at-risk seniors via a spectrum of integrated eldercare service from preventive to intervention through comprehensive programmes, including social, emotional, mental and physical, to improve their quality of life.
 
Amid the challenges in the eldercare landscape, LB undertakes constant review and adjustment to its programmes and services. Under our Community Outreach arm, we currently operate 10 Senior Activity Centres, 3 Cluster Support, 2 Senior Group Homes and Home Personal Care services. Our Befriending arm extends island-wide befriending services to socially isolated seniors. For its exemplary disclosure and corporate

column46:
Breast cancer is the most common cancer among Singaporean women. More cancers are now detected earlier, and more women are surviving longer and with better quality of life. But more research is needed to understand this disease, e.g. why some women with breast cancer cope better than others, why treatments fail, or why some women with seemingly no risk factors develop breast cancer. 

The Breast Service at TTSH has been actively involved in breast cancer research for many years. At our unit, we carry out clinical trials that look to increase the accuracy of breast imaging scans, to better predict treatment response and to improve post-surgery care. We participate in multicenter collaborations with other local and regional hospitals and partner research institutes both locally and internationally. Through this work, we have explored new drugs to treat drug-resistant cancers, developed liquid biopsy assays to detect and monitor breast cancer and have profiled tumours and blood to gain a deeper insight into the processes that govern tumour behaviour. 

This campaign seeks to raise funds for the newly established TTSH Breast Cancer Research and Education Program,.  

We thank all the donors who have helped us reach our fundraising target. We will keep this campaign open, to raise more funds for the BCRE Program, so that more can be done to understand and treat breast cancer.
column47:
In keeping with Mr Tan Tock Seng's Legacy of Giving, Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) set up its charity arm, TTSH Community Fund, in August 1995 to improve the quality of life of our patients and the community. 

Every year, our Charity disburses more than $2 million for our patient-centred programmes, and to support healthcare research, innovation and training for our staff and the community, to deliver better patient care. 

From expensive non-standard medication and breathing equipment to mobility aids, community rehabilitation programmes, and even dentures to help them eat better, TTSH Community Fund helps needy patients with their out-of-pocket medical expenses so that they can gain greater independence, improve their quality of life and enable them to integrate back into the community. 

Our Charity runs entirely on public donations. Every dollar to the Charity goes directly to support our activities. TTSH Community Fund is a registered charity with IPC status.

Thank you for registering in the Credit Suisse Fitness Fundraiser 2021 to raise money for the organizations in our local communities in the region. 

Please make a minimum donation of SGD 30 to participate. Credit Suisse will match the donation made by Credit Suisse employees, which means you are doubling your impact just by participating. To facilitate this, do ensure you use your CS email address when making the donation. Additional fundraising efforts are welcome.

Engaging in physical activity provides many mental and physical benefits and can bring out the best in us, both at work and in our personal lives. Achieving this while supporting our communities is even more meaningful. We look forward to your participation and would like to thank you in advance for supporting our charity partners.
column47:
Blood diseases such as Leukaemia, Lymphoma and Myeloma can strike any one at any time. When all other treatment has failed, a bone marrow transplant is their only chance of survival.

When patients are unable to find a matching donor within their family, they come to us in search of a Matched Unrelated Donor (MUD), who could give them a second chance at life. As finding a MUD means a healthy donor with the same DNA profile, the odds of finding that unique match is very low.

Thus since 1993, we at the Bone Marrow Donor Programme (BMDP) are committed to building and managing Singapore's only register of volunteer marrow donors. Providing hope for patients suffering from blood-related diseases.

For more information, please visit www.bmdp.org

UEN: S93SS0141J / IPC: HEF0015/G

Eye Run Champion Leg Miserables: 

Team Leg Miserables, led by A/Prof Xiaomeng Wang and her SERI Team (A/Prof Eranga Vithana, Ms.  Sock Mun Lay, Dr. Beiying Qiu, Dr. Joyce Kwan, Dr. Rui Ning Chia) are taking up a 360km run challenge to raise $1000. The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We are a team of research scientists and clinicians in SERI and we develop new treatments, biomarkers, and drug delivery systems for blinding eye diseases to help many patients save their eyesight. 

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.
column47:
Launched in July 2016, VisionSave is a novel initiative that taps on philanthropic investment to usher in innovative eye care research, treatment and delivery in Singapore and the region. It also aims to save sight and ensure optimal outcome for every patient. 

VisionSave aligns with SNEC and SERI's reputation as a centre of eye care and research excellence in Singapore, as well as the philanthropic spirit of the late SNEC founder Professor Arthur Lim, who modelled a giving spirit in both his personal and professional endeavours.


For more information, please visit our websites: https://www.visionsave.sg and https://ww.snec.com.sg

column3: A Tribute to Teaching and Allied Health Professionals
column37: Thank You for your donation. Funds will go towards the programme and services for children with special needs at Metta PreSchool @Punggol.
column38: Thank You for your donation. Funds will go towards the programme and services for children with special needs at Metta PreSchool @Punggol.
column41: Thank You for your donation. Funds will go towards the programme and services for children with special needs at Metta PreSchool @Punggol.
column46:
In recognition and appreciation of teaching and allied health professionals for their dedication and commitment to our children.

Metta PreSchool @ Punggol offers an early intervention programme for children under two to six years old with special needs, such as mild to severe Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD), Speech and Language Delay (SLD), Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorders (ADHD), Global Developmental Delays (GDD) etc. We cater to children from all races and religions.

Early Intervention aims to maximize the potential growth of all infants and children, with their unique learning needs and supports. Every child is special and each requires their individual dose of Tender Loving Care along with professional therapy.  This is what we provide for our young charges and their families. We do this daily and will continue to do so with the community's support.

Your kind donation will fund the programme and services of Metta PreSchool @ Punggol for children with special needs.
column47:
All donations will be eligible for tax exemption and it will be included automatically in your tax assessment. Receipts will be mailed out for donations of $50 & above. For donations below $50, you may contact us at finance@metta.org.sg if you require a copy. As Metta sees the importance in saving the environment, we are gradually going paperless for our receipts to all donors with effect from 1 April 2021 onwards. We thank you for your understanding to walk this journey together to protect the environment that we live in. 

-----

Founded in 1992 by Venerable Chao Khun Fa Zhao, Metta Welfare Association was registered as a charity in 1994. Endorsed by the MSF, MOH and MOE, we are a member of the National Council of Social Service, Singapore Hospice Council and Singapore Disability Sports Council. 

Motto:
Compassionate love to share 
Brightens hope to those we care

Vision:
Inspired by the Great Compassionate Vows of The Medicine Buddha, we aim to provide social services for the community, regardless of race

Eye Run Champion Nursing Power:

Team Power Nursing, led by Sister Lim Mein Chee and her nursing Team, Shuhada, Cecilia and Sharon Lui are taking up a 500km run challenge in the upcoming 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021'. Coming up on 1 October, 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021' is organised by The Singapore National Eye Centre (SNEC) and Singapore Eye Research Institute (SERI). It is virtual fundraiser for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We are a team of nurses working in SNEC and help many patients with eye diseases. The eyes are the window to our world. Without them, the world would be totally different. We hope by running and walking 500km, we can raise $5000 in the race to fight blindness.

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.
