column46:
Epilepsy is a common and potentially serious chronic neurological condition, with a reported prevalence of 4-7 per 1000 population

Did you know?

50 MILLION
people have been diagnosed with epilepsy in the world.
 
25,000
people live with epilepsy in Singapore.
 
150
new cases are diagnosed every year
 
With growing awareness about different types of epilepsies and continued improvements in diagnoses, the lives of 150 people and their families are newly impacted each year!
 
Let them know they are not alone...
 
By making a donation today, you send a powerful message that those just beginning their journey with epilepsy or are already living with epilepsy are surrounded by a compassionate community of friends and supporters.
 
Donations of $20 and above to Epilepsy Care Group (Singapore) qualify for tax relief.
column47:
Established in October 1993, Epilepsy Care Group (Singapore) (ECG) is a social service agency that addresses the needs and concerns of people with epilepsy, their families and those in the community directly affected by the condition.

ECG is registered under the Societies Act, Chapter 311 on 12 December 1995 and Charities Act, Chapter 37 on 2 October 1996 and is domiciled in the Republic of Singapore. ECG is an approved Institution of a Public Character.

ECG has a Constitution as its governing instrument.

ECG is governed by the Executive Council, which is a governing body responsible in providing strategic direction and oversight of its programmes and objectives and steering it towards fulfilling its vision and mission through good governance. Reporting to the Executive Council are Sub-Committees that look into specific areas.

column46:
Eye Run Champion Team Eytificial Intelligence:

Team Eytificial Intelligence, led by A/Prof Daniel Ting, and his 9 team members (Tan Siu Kwan Iris, Zheng Feihui, Wang Zhaoran, Li Yong, Gilbert Lim, Su Qi, Lily Yang, Laura Gutierrez, Kabilan Elangovan) will be walking/running 1000 km in the Eye Run/Cycle to create awareness about the power of using AI and digital technology in eye care delivery. Our research focus is on artificial intelligence and digital innovation for eye diseases such as diabetic retinopathy, glaucoma, age-related macular degeneration and myopia that could affect more than1 billion population worldwide. With COVID-19 pandemic crisis, this has resulted in significant impact in the Singapore and global setting in delivering appropriate and timely eye care to the patients to reduce incidence of blindness. Many countries are experiencing lock downs and resurgence of COVID-19 cases (e.g., delta variants), and AI and digital health could play a significant role in mitigating unnecessary delays in clinical consultations and interventions.  We are hoping to raise $10,000 towards research and education to continue to innovate and develop new AI and digital technologies to reduce total incidence of blindness within and outside Singapore. 

Look forward to your kind and generous support to reach my donation target! This will definitely motivate the team to innovate harder for more cutting edge technologies!

Join us in supporting VisionSave!

Eye Cycle Champion Glauco-Man Spin:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Glauco-Man Spin, led by A/Prof Shamira Perera and his fellow avid cyclists and superstar eye docs:, Prof Dan Milea, Prof Jonathan Crowston , Cl A/Prof Rahat Husain, Dr Arun Narayanaswamy and Dr Sesha Sudarshan are taking up a 900km cycle challenge to raise $7500. All proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for glaucoma. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

This 'silent thief of sight' is the number one cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. Keep an eye out for these doctors in skin-tight lycra on the road, as they spin for this challenge!

Eye Run Champion Walk the talk, jog or run:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team Walk the talk, jog or run, led by Deputy Medical Director (Clinical) CI A/Prof Edmund Wong and his SNEC colleagues, COO, Mr Jim Gu, Director of Nursing, Dr Loh Huey Peng and Dr Christine Cheng are taking up a 500km run challenge to raise $10,000. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

Everyone has the fire but champions know when to ignite the fire! We hope by taking up this challenge, it will create the awareness of good eye health  and the continuous need to develop new treatment for blinding eye diseases to help many patients save their eyesight. 

Donations will play a major role in funding the necessary research and education,  which will eventually help needy patients with sight saving surgeries and treatments for their eyes, eg cataract / glaucoma / retinal surgeries, laser treatments for glaucoma and retina, injection treatments for age related and other retinal conditions.

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column3: Decade for Decisive Action: Help Us Advocate Responsible Business towards a Sustainable Future
column37: Thank you for your contribution in helping us build better and more sustainable businesses, as well as inspiring the next generation to continue the mission!
column38: Thank you for your contribution in helping us build better and more sustainable businesses, as well as inspiring the next generation to continue the mission!

column41: Thank you for your contribution in helping us build better and more sustainable businesses, as well as inspiring the next generation to continue the mission!
column46:
We believe that everyone has a little spark of motivation to save the world, especially in the face of world-changing objectives such as combating climate change and achieving equality. With less than a decade to implement sustainable solutions to all the world's biggest challenges, we need you now, more than ever, to generate an unstoppable movement pushing for the required transformations.

The private sector plays a pivotal role in catalysing the urgent change needed to achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals: a shared blueprint of peace and prosperity, for people and planet.

Help us advocate for sustainable and socially responsible business practices. Help us nurture the future generation to be active architects of a better world. The SDGs are our best hope to achieve this.

It's time to deliver on the SDGs.

Join us in fighting the good fight. Your generosity and kindness will go a long way in furthering our mission for a more sustainable and prosperous future for all.
column47:
GCNS is the Singapore chapter of the United Nations Global Compact (UNGC). As the leading voice on corporate sustainability, we drive multi-stakeholder action to forge a more sustainable future. We champion responsible business practices through UNGC's principles in Human Rights, Environment, Labour and Anti-Corruption and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals: a shared blueprint for building inclusive, prosperous societies in which no one is left behind.

The race is on: we have less than ten years left to meet these Goals. 

Let's make this the Decade for Decisive Action. Let's make this the decade in which we reimagine ways of doing business that are both responsible and resilient. Together, let's rebuild our economies towards a future that enables all communities, our planet and businesses to thrive.

To individuals: Fundraising makes up a significant proportion of our revenue. Your contribution, no matter the amount, can help us go the extra mile. Check in with your HR too: your contributions could be fur

column46:
Eye Run Champion CI A/Prof Ho Ching Lin: 

So excited to share about The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 - the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI! This newest challenge is for the vital purpose of saving sight, and lending a helping hand to eye research and education for blindness prevention! I've signed up for this event to play a small part in this important cause, and it's kicking off soon, from 1 October to 30 November. 

I'm Ho Ching Lin, and I am motivated to take on this challenge - I'm a Senior Consultant ophthalmologist, as well as a clinician researcher and educator. I specialise in glaucoma, the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide and one of the top eye diseases linked to ageing. In Singapore alone, glaucoma is behind 40% of blindness cases!

I treat both adults and children with this disease, so I am committed to beating this 'silent thief of sight'! Also, as Director of Philanthropy and Development for the Ophthalmology & Visual Sciences Academic Clinical Programme (Eye ACP), I'm pumped and ready to lead by example in supporting VisionSave, the beneficiary of this challenge.

While I usually spend more time on the mat as a yogi, I've pledged to cover 50km on foot in The Eye Run/Cycle to create awareness for glaucoma and other blinding diseases. I hope to raise $25,000 towards research and education that will preserve the eyesight of many people. Help me reach my donation goal and join the fight against blindness today!

column46:
Eye Run Champion Glauco-Man Sprint:

Is it a Bird? Is it a Plane? No it's Glauco-Man!

Now everyone can be a superhero. Please donate so that you can support fellow superheroes who are doing research or undergoing training to treat blinding eye conditions such as glaucoma! 

Team Glauco-Man Sprint, led by Dr Jayant V Iyer along with his team of fellow doctors & friends - Dr Low Jinrong, Dr Reuben Foo, Dr Sudarshan Seshasai & Mr Jason Tan - are taking up a 250km-run challenge in the upcoming 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021'. Starting officially on 1 October, it is organized by the Singapore National Eye Centre (SNEC) and Singapore Eye Research Institute (SERI). It is a virtual fundraiser for VisionSave - proceeds raised will go towards helping SNEC/SERI uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases such as glaucoma. VisionSave will also use some of these funds to train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of our patients in Singapore. 

Glaucoma is one of the leading causes of blindness in Singapore. Team Glauco-Man Sprint aims to raise $100 per km run to reach their target of $25,000. Fueled by their motto 'We Run So That All May See', the Team hopes to get your support to raise awareness on the importance of early detection of eye diseases like glaucoma, and eye research through your generous donations. 

Please support the Glauco-Man Sprint team from SNEC/SERI and become a superhero yourself so that All May See!

Eye Run Champion Eye Power:

Team Eye Power, led by Ang Heng Pei and her SERI Team (Molly Lin, Evelina Han Jing Ying, Dawn Neo Jing Hui, Isabelle Lee Xin Yu,  Toh Li Zhen and Stephanie Chu Wai Ling) are taking up a 200km run challenge in the upcoming 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021'. Coming up on 1 October, 'The Eye Run/Cycle 2021' is organised by The Singapore National Eye Centre (SNEC) and Singapore Eye Research Institute (SERI). It is the first virtual fundraiser for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping us uncover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

"Eye research is probably not as well-known a research field as others, however, we all know how precious our sight is, having only a pair of eyes. Every day, many people have been robbed of this basic ability to see. Do you know that even common conditions like diabetes, can cause blindness?

We, at SERI, study ways to alleviate the global shortage for donor corneas, as well as to devise effective methods to deliver drugs into the eyes. We hope by running 200km, we can raise $888 in the race to prevent blindness.

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.
column47:
Launched in July 2016, VisionSave is a novel initiative that taps on philanthropic investment to usher in innovative eye care research, treatment and delivery in Singapore and the region. It also aims to save sight and ensure optimal outcome for every patient. 

VisionSave aligns with SNEC and SERI's reputation as a centre of eye care and research excellence in Singapore, as well as the philanthropic spirit of the late SNEC founder Professor Arthur Lim, who modelled a giving spirit in both his personal and professional endeavours.


For more information, please visit our websites: https://www.visionsave.sg and https://ww.snec.com.sg

column46:
Organised by Mercy Relief, the Ground Zero Race is in its fifth instalment. This race allows participants to experience a disaster survivor's journey at ground zero - the disaster site - where there is a need to collect urgent supplies required to endure the immediate aftermath of a humanitarian disaster by carrying a bag of rice and racing against time in a run for humanity. 
Due to safety measures for the COVID-19 pandemic, the Ground Zero Race is now a 'Virtual Challenge'! 
 
Now called the Ground Zero Bike+Run Virtual Challenge, we have introduced the new Cycling category to invite more people to join us in running or cycling for a good cause. Participants get to decide where and when your running/cycling track is: Be it in your neighborhood, along East Coast Park or even on the treadmill. Run/cycle solo, or team up to complete your chosen distance all at once or divide it up to fit your schedule.  

Do your part in empowering vulnerable communities in Asia Pacific. Sign up today in support of our humanitarian efforts! 

Groundzerorun.com 

RAISING AWARENESS & FUNDS FOR MERCY RELIEF 
All participants are invited to contribute to the Ground Zero Bike+Run Virtual Challenge through fundraising efforts which will be channeled towards our 'Impact Fund'. This fund will allow us to scale our impact both locally and regionally for us to reach out to more communities affected by natural disasters. Donations to our Impact Fund will enjoy a 250% tax exemption.
column47:
Headquartered in Singapore, Mercy Relief was established in 2003 to respond to human tragedies and disasters in the Asia Pacific. Today, we are Singapore's leading independent disaster relief agency with dedicated leadership, capacity building expertise and an affiliate network operating across the entire disaster management cycle.

Mercy Relief provides emergency aid within 72 hours of an international appeal in the aftermath of a disaster. The objective of our longer-term sustainable development programmes is to uplift and empower communities in five key areas: water & sanitation, shelter, sustainable livelihoods, healthcare and education. For the past 17 years, Mercy Relief has responded to more than 86 human tragedies with more than $44.6 million in relief across 26 countries. We have implemented more than 72 post disaster projects and impacted over 2.6 million lives. 

Find more information about how Mercy Relief is transforming lives across Asia at www.mercyrelief.org.

column3: A Dollar A Day by Elpis@Hideout for Dementia Singapore
column37: Your kind donation will help Dementia Singapore to provide immediate resources/support for persons with dementia & their caregivers & to bolster our vital programmes & services as well as operations.

column46:
This campaign is a collaboration between Elpis@Hideout and Dementia Singapore.

Elpis@Hideout is a Social Enterprise named after the Greek word for HOPE. Its objective is to bring hope to individuals who are marginalised and struggling, mentally or physically, to enable them to lead meaningful lives. 

Today, 1 in 10 individuals who are aged 60 years old and above in Singapore has dementia. According to the Ministry of Health, neurological diseases such as dementia are the fifth leading cause of disability in Singapore. With increased life expectancy and a rapidly ageing population, we expect the number of persons living with dementia to increase. It is therefore important to raise awareness on dementia and mental wellbeing to increase support for persons living with dementia and their caregivers. 

'A Dollar A Day' is created to raise funds sustainably for Dementia Singapore, to enable them to continue the necessary care they are providing to persons living with dementia and their families.  We want to also raise awareness on dementia which will allow for early detection. Armed with the necessary information, people living with dementia and their caregivers will be able to get the support they need much earlier.

A portion of the collections, not exceeding 30%, goes to Elpis@ Hideout for every dollar raised as part of this collaboration.
column47:
Dementia Singapore was formed in 1990 as the 'Alzheimer's Disease Association' to better serve Singapore's growing dementia community, increase awareness about dementia, and reduce the stigma surrounding the condition.
 

As Singapore's leading Social Service Agency (SSA) in specialised dementia care, Dementia Singapore aims to advocate for the needs of people living with dementia and their families; empower the community through capability-building, knowledge and consultancy; and deliver quality, person-centred care innovations.

Dementia Singapore is registered as a company limited by guarantee UEN No. 202111519K.

All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We are a team of highly empathetic professionals that share a close bond with patients as we sincerely seek to understand the difficulties and issues faced by patients of all ages and work closely with patients, caregivers and doctors to provide reassurance, support and appropriate solutions. The optometry department is a crucial part of the SNEC family and optometrists are enthusiastic to continually improve skill sets, upgrade latest scientific knowledge and bring the best care for patients. For many years, we actively commit to various voluntary charity outreach as we are fixated to bring smiles to eyes.

Driven by our motto 'overcome all adversities with positivity', we hope for your kind support in our challenge as we bring smiles to eyes together! The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
Hi everyone, I am Yancheng, a Class of 2021 graduate from Ngee Ann Polytechnic (NP)'s School of Infocomm Technology.
  
My poly journey was challenging to say the least, but I am grateful to have graduated thanks to the generosity of donors and my lecturers. With their gracious support, I am now fulfilling my dream of becoming an entrepreneur and making a positive impact on society. 
               
In 2020, I co-founded Savee.sg, a mobile application aimed at helping low-income families reduce their living expenses through cashback on retail products, food and groceries.

To my fellow graduands of Class of 2021, NP alumni and donors, I hope my journey has motivated you to support my campaign, to leave and live a legacy.

Your donations will go to the Ngee Ann Polytechnic Fund to help students in need. Your contribution, no matter the amount, will bring students like me closer to achieving our dreams and pursuing our passion.

Thank you so much!!!
column47:
Ngee Ann Polytechnic(NP) started in 1963 and is today one of Singapore's leading institutions of higher learning with more than 14,000 enrolled students in over 40 disciplines. It seeks to develop students with a passion for learning, values for life, and competencies to thrive in a global workplace.  

Donations received will be channelled to Ngee Ann Polytechnic Fund.

For more information on NP, please visit  https://www.np.edu.sg/donate/Pages/default.aspx

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team Sight Thief Chasers, led by Dr Annabel Chew and her Glaucoma clinician colleagues (Cl A/Prof Ho Ching Lin, Dr Boey Pui Yi, Dr Rachel Chong, Dr Yap Zhu Li) are taking up a 100km run challenge to raise $10,000. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

Glaucoma is a silent thief of sight, and is the leading cause of irreversible blindness worldwide. As glaucoma specialists, we take care of patients with this debilitating disease. We are running to spread the awareness that early detection and treatment of glaucoma can help prevent blindness, and enable our patients to have a good quality of life.

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
Hello Everyone. I am Dr Teo Li-Ming, Academic Vice-Chair for Clinical Services & Quality, Singhealth Anaesthesiology & Perioperative Sciences Academic Clinical Programme (ACP). As anaesthesiologists, we are involved in the entire journey of patients coming for surgery.  We continuously seek advances in clinical guidelines/pathways, patient safety and quality improvement science in the following areas - Perioperative Medicine (pre, intra & post-surgery/procedure care), Pain Medicine and Intensive Care Medicine. Your generous support will support projects that will enhance the care and well-being of our patients. 

Over this 3-month period, I aim to run 120km to do my part to garner your contributions to our cause. Looking forward to your generosity!

Eligible donations will enjoy 250% tax deduction and the donation will be automatically included in the donor's IRAS tax assessment. If you would like a receipt, please email us at giftstosgh@sgh.com.sg.
column47: The SGH Health Development Fund supports the promotion, development and provision of health related services to benefit the Singapore community at large. These initiatives include assistance to patients in need, and advances in medical research and education to improve patient care. SGH Health Development Fund is part of SingHealth Fund, (UEN 201624016E) an Institution of a Public Character. All donations received are managed and administered by SingHealth Fund

Eye Run Champion The Eviscerators:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave.

The Eviscerators, led by Dr Gillian Teh and her Oculoplastics clinician colleagues (Cl A/Prof Sunny Shen, Dr Licia Tan, Dr Lim Sing Hui, Dr Lim Xian Hui, Dr Bryan Atienza, Dr Hugo Lee and Dr Kala Sumugam) are taking up a 1000km run challenge to raise $10,000. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We are a group of runners that includes Ophthalmology residents and doctors from the Oculoplastics department of Singapore National Eye Centre. In our daily practice, we see patients with sight threatening and some potentially life threatening disorders. We also have current and past international fellows on our team, which reflects our goal to help eradicate and treat eye diseases as a collaborative effort on a global scale extending beyond Singapore. Our goal is to raise $10000, which will go towards funding research and training healthcare professionals to help "eviscerate" eye diseases. 

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
Eye Run Champion Neuro Impulses: 

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Our team of clinical neuro-ophthalmologists, neuroscientists and canine ambassadors is participating in this inaugural event to raise $15,000 by taking up a 500km walk/run challenge! We are Sharon Tow, Loo Jing Liang, Dan Milea, Shweta Singhal, Umapathi Thirugnanam, Reuben Foo, Sayantan Biswas, Muralidharan A R, and our friendly canine ambassadors are Bailey, Hershey, Kutsu and Boba. In the clinic, neuro-ophthalmologists manage patients with brain/nerve-related vision problems, while neuroscientists' research in the lab leads to improved and innovative methods of diagnosing and treating our patients. We hope to raise funds to support novel scientific and technological advances to serve our patients as well as for education of our younger generation of doctors. We look forward to your support to help us reach our goal! 

Our team Neuro Impulses' Body and Mind effort is fully engaged in preserving Vision in patients with Eye/Brain diseases. Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.
column47:
Launched in July 2016, VisionSave is a novel initiative that taps on philanthropic investment to usher in innovative eye care research, treatment and delivery in Singapore and the region. It also aims to save sight and ensure optimal outcome for every patient. 

VisionSave aligns with SNEC and SERI's reputation as a centre of eye care and research excellence in Singapore, as well as the philanthropic spirit of the late SNEC founder Professor Arthur Lim, who modelled a giving spirit in both his personal and professional endeavours.


For more information, please visit our websites: https://www.visionsave.sg and https://ww.snec.com.sg

column46:
Eye Run Champion Team 'Eat, Pray, Run Lah!' :

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team 'Eat, Pray, Run Lah!' lead by Dr Eva Fenwick and a group of clinician scientists and researchers at SERI (Ester Lee, Amudha Aravindhan, Angelina Lee, Ryan Man, Kodi Goh Shek Ming Wei and Preeti Gupta) are aiming to run 400km to raise $1000 for VisionSave. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.  

The team belongs to Population Health Research (PHR) in SERI. One of the main research focuses of PHR is creating computerized, AI-driven questionnaires that measure the impact of eye diseases and vision impairment on people's quality of life, and implementing these novel instruments into clinical care to better harness the patient's voice.

Fueled by food and prayers, we hope to take up this 400km run challenge to support innovative research to reduce vision loss and blindness from AMD and improve quality of life for AMD patients as part of the Translational Asian Age-related macular degeneration Programme (TAAP).

Join us in supporting VisionSave lah! The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

Eye Cycle Champion Visionary Pedal Pushers:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Clin Assoc Prof Edmund Wong is a retinal surgeon at Singapore National Eye Centre, together with a multi-disciplinary group of friends, Dr Vincent Lai, Ms Christy Zheng, Dr Teo Swee Guan, Dr Lau Kean Wah will aim to ride a cumulative distance of 2,500 km over 2 months to raise $10,000 for VisionSave. All proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients. Age-related macular degeneration, diabetic eye disease, and genetic eye diseases can be very devastating to anyone afflicted with these diseases. We believe friends and family are important in health and disease. Please donate generously and support this worthy cause, as we motivate each other towards completing our target!

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
The Boys' Brigade in Singapore is relocating to new Headquarter premises at 10 Kwong Avenue soon, where we will continue our mission in mentoring and training Boys and youths into responsible citizens and leaders in society. The premises will be developed in phases across 2021 and 2022.

Every dollar you donate to 26th BB Company's fundraising campaign not only helps to build up our new Headquarters, but it is foundational in fulfilling our fresh visions of nurturing young lives and promoting intergenerational community life in the surrounding precinct! We hope to start new BB Companies at the premises and also provide new engagement activities to serve the community as well as BB members and stakeholders.

So, join 26th Coy today in creating a supportive and fun learning hub with exciting adventure, leadership and values-in-action programmes for BB Boys, our stakeholders and the community!

We hope for your generous support in carrying out our mission, as we have done for the past 91 years in Singapore! We strive to continue the good works with our stakeholders and journey together towards our centennial year in 2030!
column47:
The Boys' Brigade (BB) was founded in Glasgow, Scotland, in 1883 as a uniformed youth organisation. Today, the movement has spread across the globe with over half a million members worldwide. 
 
The BB in Singapore was founded on 12 January 1930.  We employ a holistic approach in the development of youths. Through our programme, we hope for our youths to be world-ready, with the passion to act on their dreams and to serve and care for the community.

Boys and Youths discover more about themselves, overcome challenges and broaden their perspectives through our exciting outdoor adventure activities, meaningful community projects and enrichment programmes. Increasingly, the emphasis is on leadership development, team building, life skills, adventure activities and community service.

The BB members' experiential learning journey takes place in three specially designed programmes, namely Juniors Programme (Primary Schools), Seniors Programme (Secondary Schools) and Primers Programme (Polys, JCs and ITEs).

column3: Breakthrough in Learning Difficulties - The Irlen Method
column37: Thank you! Your donation provides Irlen lenses to help underprivileged students at Spectra Secondary School under the Financial Assistance Scheme to treat their Visual Processing Disorder.

column46:
As part of Rotary's commitment to serve to change lives, Rotary E-Club of 3310 has invited the partnership of Spectra Secondary School to embark on a project with the use of Irlen Lens to treat students with Visual Processing Disorder (Irlen Syndrome), a neurological disorder where the brain has difficulty processing certain wavelengths of light.
Students with this condition suffer from visual stress which can cause discomfort and difficulty with reading, copying, and writing. They are not able to see prints clearly because they see distortions such as blurring and shaking words which makes reading painful for them. They also experience physical symptoms like headaches, dizziness, eye strain, fatigue, nausea, and migraine. Visual processing and learning are intimately related. Hence, with Visual Processing Disorder (Irlen Syndrome), one's ability to learn will be compromised due to the difficulty of processing of visual information.
Irlen Syndrome can be treated with the use of Irlen lenses which filter out the wavelengths of light that stress the brain. This alleviates the symptoms of Visual Processing Disorder, enabling the individuals to process visual information more accurately and comfortably. The cost of a pair of Irlen lenses is $500.
With your generous donation, we wish to issue these Irlen lenses to help underprivileged students at Spectra Secondary School who are currently under Financial Assistance Scheme to treat their Visual Processing Disorder (Irlen Syndrome).
column47: FRCS is the umbrella body that unites the 23 Rotary Clubs in Singapore and is the charity arm of Rotary in Singapore. Over the past 24 years, the Foundation has transformed gifts into impactful service projects that changed lives in the community - bringing to fruition, the Rotarian ideal of "Service Above Self".  In so doing, promoting the core Rotarian values of Fellowship and Global Understanding; Ethics and Integrity; Diversity; Vocational Expertise, Service and Leadership within and beyond the Rotarian community.

column46:
Eye Run and Cycle Champion Fiona Leong: 

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

I am a Senior Staff Nurse in the pre-surgery department of SNEC. I do assessments for patients who are listed for surgery and provide pre-surgery counselling. A few years ago, I had an accident and the injury affected my mobility. I was not able to stand for long hours. I began my slow recovery. As part of my road to recovery, I am setting myself a challenge of running and walking 200km as well as cycle 300km to raise $5,000 for VisionSave. This will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

I am also a lupus patient and I know as long as you never give up, you will overcome the adversity and reach your goal. We only live one life and I believe that everyone can make a positive difference to someone's life. I look forward to your support to motivate me to complete my challenge.

Join me in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow- A second Sight, A second Life.

Eye Run Champion Team Eye Believe: 

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team Eye Believe led by Dr Chinmayi Vyas, consist of a diverse group of clinicians, scientists, and administrators at the Singapore National Eye Centre and Singapore Eye Research Institute (Ms Callyn Kan, Ms Jocelyn Cheong, Mr Waseem Ahamed, Dr Cheong Kai Xiong, Dr Majid Al Shaiibi, Dr Rubamalar Gunatheesan and Dr Jaclyn Neo). The team aims to run/walk 500km to raise $1000 for Visionsave. All proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We will take on the challenge to support research under the Translational Asian Age-related macular degeneration Programme (TAAP) which adopts a broad-based inter-linked bench to bedside to population approach to address crucial medical research questions and target clinical gaps in AMD to reduce vision loss and blindness. 

Help us reach our donation goal and join the fight against blindness.

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

Eye Run Champion Team SNEC-SERI uveitis

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team Team SNEC-SERI uveitis, led by Dr Anita Chan and her teammates, Dr Jay Siak, Sam Ngiam (SERI), Wu Meihui (SERI), Candice Ho (SERI), Mona Wang (SERI) and Myoe Naing Lynn (SERI) are taking up an 100km run challenge to raise $10,000. All proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

SNEC Uveitis (Ocular inflammation and immunology department) clinicians provide specialised care for complex eye infections, inflammation and cancers.
Our SERI TOPP research team uses traditional and novel technology to aid new discoveries. We strive to use science and clinical knowledge to improve the diagnosis of uveitis. 

Please support our team of clinicians and scientific researchers as we run to reach our donation target for VisionSave. We hope that this will help us develop new diagnostic tests that will benefit our patients with viral eye diseases and eye cancers.
 
Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

Eye Run Champion Myopia Walk for Good Sight:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Team Myopia Walk for Good Sight, led by Prof Saw Seang Mei and her SERI Myopia Unit team mates- Dr Foo Li Lian, A/Prof Donny Hoang, Naimah Binte Ismail, Tan Chun Wei and Xu Lingqian are taking up a 300km walk & run challenge to raise $3,000. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

Our team is in myopia research. Singapore is the myopia capital of the world and our research helps in the fight against the prevention, control and treatment of myopia and its complications across all ages. We are taking up this 300km challenge to increase the awareness of good sight for myopic eyes. Help us fight myopia!

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
Dear Former Boys, Primers and Alumni of 12th Independent Company;

Hope you are keeping well and in the best of health. 

A few of our former 12I Boys/Primers/Officers are intending to do a special fundraising project for the new Boys' Brigade Headquarters located in 10 Kwong Avenue. BBHQ is moving to a new campus after several decades at Zion Road.

As we've been impacted by the BB ministry, we have decided to adopt a room/hall in the new BBHQ, for which an appreciation plaque will be placed outside the room. It will be dedicated to our former 12I BB Captain and Officer Mr Jonathan Ng Joo Foon, for his ministry in nurturing generations of men and women through the BB, and presenting this special 'gift' to him next year in 2022, his retirement year, potentially with a physical event once the restrictions from the pandemic have been eased.

We have decided to target a fund-raising target of $20,000 in the first instance, and hope to raise it by the end of 2021 (31 Dec 2021).

We hope to attract donations of $250/$500/$1,000 per former BB Boy/Primer. Of course we will welcome any amount nonetheless.

If possible, Please let Gareth or Oliver know once you have donated by Facebook messenger so we can also invite you for the naming event when conditions permit hopefully in 2022.

All donations are tax deductible at 250%.
column47:
The Boys' Brigade (BB) was founded in Glasgow, Scotland, in 1883 as a uniformed youth organisation. Today, the movement has spread across the globe with over half a million members worldwide. 
 
The BB in Singapore was founded on 12 January 1930.  We employ a holistic approach in the development of youths. Through our programme, we hope for our youths to be world-ready, with the passion to act on their dreams and to serve and care for the community.

Boys and Youths discover more about themselves, overcome challenges and broaden their perspectives through our exciting outdoor adventure activities, meaningful community projects and enrichment programmes. Increasingly, the emphasis is on leadership development, team building, life skills, adventure activities and community service.

The BB members' experiential learning journey takes place in three specially designed programmes, namely Juniors Programme (Primary Schools), Seniors Programme (Secondary Schools) and Primers Programme (Polys, JCs and ITEs).

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

The Eye Poppers, led by Dr Yvonne Chung and her teammates (June Leong, Kel Song, Yeo Su Lyn) are taking up a 500km run challenge to raise $10,000. All the proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

Dr Chung is an oculoplastic surgeon specialising in thyroid and orbital eye disease. Fueled by their running slogan 'Saving eyes, slaying styes one kilometre at a time'
, the Eye Poppers hope to raise the awareness of thyroid eye diseases and the importance of good eye health. Thyroid eye disease complications have a major impact on patients' physical and mental health. We need your support to raise $10,000 for VisionSave.  

Join us in supporting VisionSave. The donation that you contribute today, will lead to a better eye treatment tomorrow.

column46:
On November 3rd, I will be performing at the Wild Rice theatre in Singapore raising much needed funds for this wonderful not-for-profit organisation, whose mission is to provide an open forum for the shared experience of theatre - celebrating our diversity; reflecting on the problems and possibilities of our times; and presenting productions that inspire, challenge and entertain. 

The theatre extends deep into the Singapore community nurturing talent from 5 years old. They also allow middle aged bankers to occasionally let their hair down for a great cause! So I would massively appreciate any donations in aid of this theatre, which like many organisations, has had its challenges during Covid, but hopefully is now emerging out of this difficult period. Thank you! Love, Kevin Burke

Show Details: 
FAGHAG
https://www.wildrice.com.sg/event/28699-faghag-2
Wed 3 Nov 2021, 7.30pm 
The Ngee Ann Kongsi Theatre @ WILD RICE
107 North Bridge Rd #04-08 FUNAN, Singapore 179105
column47:
Wild Rice was founded in 2000 by Ivan Heng, an internationally acclaimed and award-winning theatre practitioner, and is recognised today as one of Singapore's leading professional theatre companies.

Our mission is to provide an open forum for the shared experience of theatre: celebrating our diversity; reflecting on the problems and possibilities of our times; and presenting productions that inspire, challenge and entertain.

A commitment to the highest standards informs every aspect of Wild Rice's creative work, which is first and foremost a celebration of Singapore's theatrical talent. By producing and touring productions that are distinctively local in flavour and yet universal in vision and concerns, Wild Rice creates memorable experiences for audiences in Singapore and across the world.

Our mission to build a theatre culture also extends to the wider community through the following divisions:
- Wild Rice Academy, which offer drama and training programmes to nurture young talents from the ages of 5 to 1

Eye Run Champion Eye Engineering Runners:

The Eye Run/Cycle 2021 is the first virtual fundraiser by SNEC and SERI to raise funds for VisionSave. 

Eye Engineering Runners Team, led by Dr Michael Girard and his teammates, Dr Fabian Braeu, Dr Royston Tan, Dr Mo Deng, Dr Satish Panda, Dr Raymond Najjar, Dr George Barbastathis, Dr Ong Chi Wei, Dr Elizabeth Lee are taking up a 1250km run challenge to raise $2,000. All proceeds will go towards helping discover new ways to detect, diagnose and develop future treatments for eye diseases. It will also help train healthcare professionals to meet the ever-evolving needs of the patients.

We are a running team composed of eye engineers and scientists, several of whom also belong to the Ophthalmic Engineering & Innovation Laboratory (OEIL) at SERI (https://www.ophthalmic.engineering). Our team strongly believe that it is critical to bring Engineering to the clinic for the benefit of The Blind and The Visually Impaired.  Engineering and Mathematical tools (such as those used for designing aircrafts or for space travel) could allow us to better diagnose and treat eye diseases, and eventually allow us to develop the first bionic eye. Driven by our mission, we are challenging ourselves to achieve our target of 1250km. We look forward to your support to help us reach our donation target too, as we motivate each other towards completing our target!

Join us in supporting VisionSave.

column46:
'BOWLS' is back! Our annual BOWLS appeal took a hiatus last year but we are excited to restart the appeal to raise funds for medical and food in aid of street and shelter animals.

Rescuing an animal is not the end of the road, it is the very first step. The work of treating the animals' illness and rehabilitating them to fit into a home environment can take months and sometimes years. Through the process, the animals will need food and medical support. 

Our new facility  allows us to continue actively with our Stray Management Scheme which is in line with the nationwide TNRM programme. We hope to continue to have the means to gradually take dogs off the streets and place them in loving homes to call their own in due time. With more funds, we will also be able to feed more hungry animals and medicate more ill and injured street or shelter animals in need.
column47:
Causes for Animals (Singapore) Limited (CAS) is an animal welfare charity set up and registered in 2013 to support the needs of local animal welfare in Singapore. CAS employs programmes and policies to promote best practice with involve ethical, sustainable and compassionate treatment of these animals.

Our current adoption  centre  houses up to 50 rescued dogs to be rehabilitated for rehoming. CAS has a no-kill policy of animals placed in our care. Animals are given optimal care and decisions on medical treatment rely upon vet advice. Medical assistance is also provided to injured dogs rescued by third parties. Shelter operational costs, veterinary services and medical supplies average $30,000 month.

CAS relies mainly on public donations for funding.

column37: Your contribution has helped Jega with his literacy support!

column41: Your contribution has helped Jega with his literacy support!
column46:
Jega is 40 years old and has dyslexia.  He is a participant in the Mediacorp documentary, Write of Passage, which showcased him receiving life-changing literacy intervention over a 3-month period.  Our work with Jega highlighted the need for him to receive a longer period of intervention on top of the 3-months he received.  DAS would recommend that Jega receive a further 24-months of support so that he can achieve his life and employment goals.  

Jega was selected for intervention at DAS where he underwent a psychological assessment and was diagnosed with dyslexia in May 2021.  He had specialist intervention at DAS International for 20 x 1.5hr sessions from 25 May to 11 August 2021.

We are delighted with Jega's progress and his enthusiasm to learn.  His progress was very encouraging, and we are impressed with what he has been able to achieve in this short period of intervention which has revealed his true potential in learning. However, his 30 hours of literacy intervention for the documentary series only highlighted the necessity for continued support after the completion of these 20 sessions.  Jega's continued learning journey is critical for his desire to become an independent person and not allow his dyslexia to stand in the way of his life aspirations.

It is unfortunate that Jega received his basic education at a time when dyslexia was little known and effective forms of intervention for the condition was not provided for in mainstream school. Nonetheless, it is
column47:
In our efforts to continuously provide and improve our professional services to dyslexics in Singapore, we rely heavily on public donations to sustain our daily operations. DAS provides more than $1 million in bursaries every year and this figure is rising. Without support from the generous people and organisations of Singapore, this support would not be possible. Please donate to DAS.

Donations received will go directly to the bursary fund for low-income families to access our services.

column3: Trees of the World 2021 at Singapore Botanic Gardens
column37: Thank you for donating and supporting the Singapore Botanic Gardens' research, outreach and education programmes to conserve our natural heritage and connect our community with nature in Singapore!
column38: Thank you for donating and supporting the Singapore Botanic Gardens' research, outreach and education programmes to conserve our natural heritage and connect our community with nature in Singapore!
column39: Thank you for donating and supporting the Singapore Botanic Gardens' research, outreach and education programmes! Your contribution enables you (individual) to decorate a tree in the Gardens.
column40: Thank you for donating and supporting the Singapore Botanic Gardens' research, outreach and education programmes! Your contribution enables you (corporate) to decorate a tree in the Gardens.
column41: Thank you for your generous donation. Your donation will support  research, conservation, education and outreach projects in Singapore Botanic Gardens.
column46:
The Trees of the World fundraiser supports the work of the Singapore Botanic Gardens in research, conservation, education and outreach. As a leading centre for tropical botany in Southeast Asia, the Gardens' research programmes have increased our understanding of the diversity and conservation needs of plants in Singapore and the wider region. 

With over 160 years of rich cultural and botanical heritage, Trees of the World also supports the Gardens' outreach to young and old alike, connecting the generations with each other and with nature, and encouraging greater environmental stewardship for all ages. 

This year, we are inviting individuals and corporates to decorate 200 trees in the Gardens for a holiday tree light up from 4 December 2021 to 2 January 2022. 100% of donations* will go towards supporting the work of the Gardens and all operational costs will be funded by the National Parks Board.

After the festive light up, these 200 trees will be planted in our Nature Reserves, Parks and Gardens in support of our OneMillionTrees movement.

*Kindly consider making a donation from 28 October 2021 onwards when this campaign could be eligible for a matching grant that could increase your gift value by 40%
column47: Established by the National Parks Board (NParks) in 2002, Garden City Fund is managed independently as a charity, where 100% of donations raised go towards projects it supports. The charity hopes to cultivate a love for the environment, promote a sense of ownership, and encourage the community to play a part in preserving Singapore's legacy as a lush and vibrant City in Nature. Through partnerships with organisations and individuals, GCF provides a platform for the community to be involved and contribute towards conservation, research, outreach and education initiatives.
